The translation "She is not easily movable" explicitly states an intrinsic characteristic of the Earth (its difficulty in being moved due to its mass) as the reason for this harshness. This rewrites an implication about the Earth's treatment into an explicit statement about its nature, providing a causal clarification.

The French "un tour immense" (an immense turn/trip) is translated as "an immense circuit". While "tour" can imply a circuit in context, "circuit" is more specific, explicitly denoting a complete path or loop. This translation clarifies the nature of the vast movement of celestial bodies around the Earth as a closed trajectory.

chunks.source_manual: <P010>Oh! répliqua-t-elle, le Soleil & les Astres sont tout de feu, le mouvement ne leur coúte rien; mais la Terre ne paroît guere portative. Et croiriez-vous, repris-je, si vous n'en aviez point l'expérience, que ce fût quelque chose de bien portatif, qu'un gros Navire monté de cent cinquante pièces de Canon, chargé de plus de trois mille hommes, & d'une très grande nombre de Marchandises? Cependant il ne faut qu'un petit soufle de vent pour le faire aller sur l'eau, parce que l'eau est liquide, & que se laissant diviser avec facilité, elle résiste peu au mouvement du Navire. Ainsi la Terre, toute massive qu'elle est, est aisément portée dans la matiere celeste, qui est mille fois plus fluide que l'eau, & qui remplit tout ce grand espace où nagent les Planètes. Et où faudroit-il que la Terre fût cramponnée pour résister au mouvement de cette matière céleste, & ne pas s'y laisser emporter? C'est comme si une petite boule de bois pouvoit ne pas suivre le courant d'une Riviere.</P010>
chunks.target_manual: <P008>Oh, says she, the Sun and Stars consist of fire, their motion costs them little; but the Earth seems not easily manageable. And would you believe, said I, if you did not know it by experience, that a great Ship mounted with an hundred and fifty pieces of Artilery, man'd with above three thousand men, and well laden with Merchandise, would be a thing easily portative? in the mean time a little puff of Wind suffices to drive it upon the Water; because the Water being liquid, is easily divided, and makes no resistance to the motion of the Ship; so the Earth, though an unweildy mass, is easily carried through the celestial matter, which is ten thousand times more fluid than Water, and fills all that vast space where the Planets swim. And where is it necessary that the Earth should be riveted to resist the motion of that Celestial matter? 'Tis as if a little Boul of Wood could be able not to follow the Current of a River.</P008>
explanations: The French phrase "toute massive qu'elle est," meaning "however massive it is" or "as massive as it is," primarily denotes the Earth's large physical mass. The English translation "though an unwieldy mass" explicitates the *implication* of this great mass in the context of movement, which is the inherent difficulty in moving or managing such an object. The adjective "unwieldy" directly expresses this difficulty of handling due to size and weight, a concept that is only implied in the original French by the term "massive" before the contrast with "est aisément portée" (is easily carried). The translator's choice spells out this implied characteristic, potentially to heighten the contrast or ensure the reader grasps the challenge.

chunks.source_manual: <P011>Mais, répliqua-t-elle encore, comment la Terre avec tout son poids se soûtient- elle sur votre matiere celeste qui doit être bien legere, puisqu'elle est si fluide? Ce n'est pas à dire, répondis-je, que ce qui est fluide, soit plus leger. Que dites-vous de notre gros Vaisseau, qui avec tout son poids est plus léger que l'eau, puisqu'il y surnage? Je ne veux plus vous dire rien, dit-elle comme en colere, tant que vous aurez le gros Vaisseau. Mais m'assurez-vous bien qu'il n'y ait rien à craindre sur une pirouette aussi legere que vous me faites la Terre? Eh bien, luy répondis-je, faisons porter la Terre par quatre Elephans, comme font les Indiens. Voicy bien un autre Système, s'écria-t-elle. Du moins j'aime ces Gens-là d'avoir pourveu à leur seureté, & fait de bons fondemens, au lieu que nous autres Coperniciens, nous sommes assez inconsideres pour vouloir bien nager à l'aventure dans cette matiere celeste. Je gage que si les Indiens savoient que la Terre fût le moins du monde en peril de se mouvoir, ils doubleroient les Elephans.</P011> <P012>Cela le meriteroit bien, repris-je, <NCP>en riant de sa pensée</NCP>, il ne faut point s'épargner les Elephans pour dormir en assurance, & si vous en avez besoin pour cette nuit, nous en mettrons dans notre systême autant qu'il vous plaira; ensuite nous les retrancherons peu à peu, à mesure que vous vous rassurerez. Serieusement, reprit-elle, je ne crois pas dés à present qu'ils me soient fort necessaires, & je me sens assez de courage pour oser tourner. Vous irez bien-tost encore plus loin, répliquai-je, vous tournerez avec plaisir, & vous vous ferez sur ce Systême des idées réjouissantes. Quelquefois, par exemple, je me figure que je suis suspendu en l'air, & que j'y demeure sans mouvement pendant que la Terre tourne sous moy en vingt-quatre heures, & que je vois passer sous mes yeux tous ces visages differens, les uns blancs, les autres noirs, les autres bazannez, les autres olivâtres, que je voy d'abord des Chapeaux, & puis des Turbans, & puis des têtes cheveluës, & puis des Têtes rases; tantôt des Villes à clochers, tantôt des Villes à longues aiguilles qui ont des Croissants, tantôt des Villes à Tours de Porcelaine, tantôt de grands Païs qui n'ont que des Cabanes; icy, des vastes Mers; là des Deserts épouvantables; enfin toute cette variété infinie qui est sur la surface de la Terre.</P012>
chunks.target_manual: <P009>But, says she again, how is the Earth with all its weight supported in your Celestial matter, which being so fluid must needs be very light? That's not to be allow'd, said I, that what is more fluid is more light. What do you say to your great Vessel; which with all its weight must needs be lighter than the Water, because it swims upon it. Ile say no more to you, says she, as though angry, as long as you have that great Vessel. But can you assure me that there's nothing to be fear'd upon such a Shuttlecock or Whirligigg, as you make the Earth? Well, says I, let us carry the Earth upon four Elephants, as the Indians do. See, says she, another kind of System; yet truly, I like those people that provide for their security, and lay a good foundation; whereas we Copernicans in my opinion are rash enough to attempt to swim at a venture in that Celestial matter. Ile hold a Wager, that if the Indians knew the Earth were in the least danger in the world of being mov'd, they'd double their Elephants 'Twill be worth the while, said I, laughing at her Fancy, never spare an Elephant to sleep in security, and if you have occasion for them this night, we'l put as many in our System as you please, and afterward take them out again by little and little, as you begin to be more and more assured. Seriously, says she, I believe from this time forward I shall not much need them; for I find my self couragious enough to turn. You shall presently, says I, go yet farther, and have delightful Idea's of this System. Sometimes, for example, I fancy with my self that I hang in the Air, and continue there without motion while the Earth turns under me four and twenty hours, and I see pass under me all these different appearances, some white, some black, some swarthy, others tawny, now Hats, then Turbants, some Heads with Hair, others bald, by and by Towns with Steeples, then Towns with long Spires and Crescents, next Towns with Towers of Porcelain, then a large Country that has nothing but Cabins, here a vast Sea, there a frightful Desart, and in fine, all the infinite variety upon the face of the Earth.</P009>
target_segments: in my opinion are rash enough
explanations: The French "une pirouette" (a spin/twirl) is a general term for a spinning motion. The translator makes this image more concrete and explicit by providing "a Shuttlecock or Whirligigg," specific examples of light, spinning, or mobile objects. This expansion spells out the *kind* of light, spinning thing the Marquise is likening the Earth to, using familiar imagery for the English reader of the period.

The French "nous sommes assez inconsideres" (we are thoughtless/rash enough) is an observation made by the Marquise. The translator adds the phrase "in my opinion," explicitly marking the statement as her subjective viewpoint. While the speaker's perspective is implied in the original through the context of her speech, the addition of this phrase makes the subjective nature of her judgment overtly stated.

The French "est plus léger" (is lighter), used in the phrase "est plus léger que l'eau, puisqu'il y surnage" (is lighter than water, because it swims upon it), states a factual consequence. The translation "must needs be lighter" explicitly emphasizes the logical necessity or inevitability of this consequence, which is derived from the stated evidence (swimming). This spells out the strength of the logical inference that was less overtly stressed in the original's simple statement of fact.

chunks.source_manual: <P013>En verité, dit-elle, tout cela mériteroit bien que l'on donnât vingt-quatre heures de son temps à le voir. Ainsi donc dans le même lieu où nous sommes à present, je ne dis pas dans ce Parc, mais dans ce même lieu, à le prendre dans l'air, il y passe continuellement d'autres Peuples qui prennent notre place, & au bout de vingt-quatre heures nous y revenons.</P013>
chunks.target_manual: <P010>Truly, says she, it would be four and twenty hours well spent to see all this; so that in the same place where we are, I do not mean in this Park, but in the same place in the Air, other people are continually passing, and take our place, and in four and twenty hours we return here again.</P010>
explanations: The French phrase "à le prendre dans l'air," which follows "dans ce même lieu" (in this same place), literally means "to take it in the air" or more idiomatically "considering it in the air" or "if we consider its position in the air." It serves as a nuanced clarification, indicating that the "place" being referred to is a point in space, not the physical park on Earth. The English translation renders this as "in the same place in the Air." The segment "in the Air" directly modifies "place," making the spatial nature of the location an explicit attribute. The translator has changed the French construction, which implies a specific way of conceptualizing or qualifying the "place" (i.e., from an aerial/spatial perspective), into a direct statement about the location of the "place." This simplification makes the intended distinction more immediately explicit, removing the conditional or perspectival nuance of "à le prendre" (to take it/to consider it) and presenting the spatial quality as a given characteristic of the "place."

chunks.source_manual: <P014>Copernic, luy répondis-je, ne le comprendroit pas mieux. D'abord il passera par icy des Anglois qui raisonneront peut-être de quelque dessein de Politique avec moins de gayeté que nous ne raisonnons de notre Philosophie; ensuite viendra une grànde Mer, & il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau qui n'y sera pas si à son aise que nous. Après cela paraîtront des <IIM>Iroquois</IIM>, qui mangeront tout vif quelque prisonnier de guerre, qui fera semblant de ne s'en pas soucier; des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso, qui n'employeront tout leur temps qu'à préparer le Repas de leurs Maris, & à se peindre de bleu les lévres & les sourcils pour plaire aux plus <IIM> vilains Hommes du monde</IIM>; des Tartares qui iront fort devotement en Pelerinage vers ce Grand Prêtre, qui ne sort jamais d'un lieu obseur, où il n'est éclairé que par des Lampes, à la lumière desquelles on l'adore; de belles Circassiennes qui ne feront aucune façon d'accorder tout au premier venu, hormis ce qu'elles croyent qui appartient essentiellement à leurs Maris; de petits Tartares qui iront voler des Femmes pour les Turcs & pour les <IIM>Persans</IIM>; enfin, nous qui debiterons peut-être encore des <NCE>rêveries</NCE>.</P014>
chunks.target_manual: <P011>Copernicus himself, says I, could not apprehend it better; by and by you'l see some English men pass this way debating some point of Policy, but not so airily as we do our Philosophy; then comes a great Sea, where you'l see a Ship that possibly will not be so much at case as we are; afterward appear the Irroquoi's eating alive some Prisoner of War, who seems not much to heed it; then Women of the Land of Iesso, who spend their whole time in preparing Food for their Husbands, and painting their Lips and Eyebrows blue, to please the most villanous sort of men in the world; next Tartars going in Pilgrimage with great Devotion to that great Priest, who lives always shut up in a Hole where he has no Light, but a Lamp, by which they adore him; then come the fair Circassians, who make no scruple of granting all at first sight? only what they think belongs essentially to their Husbands. Then the little Tartars, who steal Women for the Turks and Persians; and lastly, we who possibly shall yet find other extravagant Inventions.</P011>
source_segments: il passera par icy des Anglois
il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau
des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso
target_segments: you'l see some English men pass this way
then Women of the Land of Iesso
explanations: The French 'Copernic' simply refers to the astronomer. The English translation 'Copernicus himself' adds the emphatic reflexive pronoun 'himself,' making explicit the implied high regard or surprise that even such an eminent figure would be impressed or understand no better.

The French 'il passera par icy des Anglois' (Englishmen will pass by here) uses an impersonal construction. The English 'you'l see some English men pass this way' makes the Marquise's (the 'you') act of observation explicit, shifting from a general prediction to her direct perceptual experience.

The French 'il se pourra trouver en ce lieu-là quelque Vaisseau' (it might be that a ship is found there) is an impersonal passive construction. The English 'where you'l see a Ship' makes the Marquise's act of observation explicit, directly involving her as the viewer of the scene.

The French 'des Femmes de la Terre de Jesso' introduces an item in an ongoing list. The English 'then Women of the Land of Iesso' adds the adverb 'then,' explicitly marking the sequential progression of the described scenes for the reader.

The French 'des Tartares' continues the enumeration of peoples. The English 'next Tartars' adds the adverb 'next,' which explicitly spells out the sequential relationship of this group to the preceding one in the list.

The French 'un lieu obseur' (an obscure/dark place) provides a general description. The English 'a Hole' makes this description more specific and concrete, explicitly evoking a small, confined, and possibly squalid space, thus adding a vividness and interpretation not explicitly stated in the original.

The French 'de belles Circassiennes' introduces the next group in the narrator's imagined sequence. The English 'then come the fair Circassians' explicitly adds the sequential marker 'then' and the verb of appearance 'come,' spelling out their arrival in the imagined panorama and its order.

The French 'accorder tout au premier venu' means to grant everything to the first person who comes along, or indiscriminately. The English 'granting all at first sight' makes explicit a specific temporal condition for this granting, suggesting an immediacy (upon seeing the person) that is a more defined interpretation of 'au premier venu'.

The French 'de petits Tartares' continues the list of diverse groups of people. The English 'Then the little Tartars' adds the transitional adverb 'Then,' explicitly marking this item's place in the sequence of the enumeration.

The French 'rêveries' (daydreams, musings, fantasies) is a relatively broad term. The English 'extravagant Inventions' makes this more specific by explicitly characterizing these thoughts as 'Inventions,' implying a degree of fabrication, and qualifying them with 'extravagant,' thereby adding an interpretive layer regarding their nature and quality.

chunks.source_manual: <P015>Il est assez plaisant, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, d'imaginer ce que vous venez de me dire; mais si je voyois tout cela d'en haut, je voudrais avoir la liberté de hâter ou d'arrêter le mouvement de la Terre, selon que les objets me plairont plus ou moins, & je vous assure que je ferais passer bien vite ceux qui s'embarrassent de Politique, ou qui mangent leurs Ennemis; mais il y en a d'autres pour qui j'aurois de la curiosité. J'en aurais pour ces Belles Circassiennes, par exemple, elles ont un usage qui mr paroit assez particulier. C'est qu'elle sont si belles, luy dis-je, que leurs Maris trovent dans leurs faveurs un superflu qu'ils abandonnent aux Etrangers. Les Femmes de ces Païs icy sont donc bien laides aux prix d'elles, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, car le Maris ne relâchent rien. Cela est cause qu'on prend davantage, repliqay-je, au lieu que...Taisez-vous, interrompit-elle, je ne veux plus dire de folies, aussi bien il me vient une difficulté sérieuse. Si la Terre tourne, nous changeons d'air à chaque moment, & nous respirons toûjours celuy d'un autre Païs. Nullement, Madame, répondis-je, l'air qui environne la Terre ne s'étend que jusqu'à une certaine hauteur, peut-être jusqu'à 20 lieües, il nous suit, & tourne avec nous. Vous avez veu mille fois l'ouvrage d'un Ver à soye, ou ces Coques que ces petits animaux travaillent avec tant d'art pour s'y emprisonner. Elles sont d'une soye fort serrée, mais elles sont couvertes d'un certain duvet fort leger & fort lâche. C'est ainsi que la Terre, qui est assez solide, est couverte depuis sa surface jusqu'à vinght lieües de hauteur tout au plus, d'une espèce de duvet, qui est l'air, & toute la Coque de Ver à soye tourne en même temps. Au-delà de l'air est la matiere celeste, incomparablement plus pure, plus subtile, & même plus agitée que luy.</P015> <P016>Vous me présentez la Terre sous des idées bien méprisables, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. C'est pourtant sur cette Coque de Ver à soye qu'il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres, & qu'il règne de tous côtés une si grande agitation. Oüy, répondis-je, & pendant ce temps-là la Nature qui n'entre point en connaissance de tous ces petits mouvements particuliers, nous emporte tous ensemble d'un mouvement général, & se joüe de la petite boule.</P016> <P017>Il me semble, reprit-elle, qu'il est ridicule d'être sur quelque chose qui tourne, & de se tourmenter tant; mais le malheur est qu'on n'est pas assuré qu'on tourne; car enfin, à ne vous rien celer, toutes les précautions que vous prenez pour empêcher qu'on ne s'aperçoive du mouvement de la Terre, me sont suspectes. Est-il possible qu'il ne laissera pas quelque petite marque sensible à laquelle on le reconnaisse?</P017> <P018>Les mouvements les plus naturels, répondis-je, & les plus ordinaires, sont ceux qui se font le moins sentir, & cela est vray jusque dans la Morale. Le mouvement de l'Amour propre nous est si naturel, que le plus souvent nous ne le sentons pas, & que nous croyons agir par d'autres principes. Ah! vous <IIM>moralisez</IIM>, dit- elle, quand il est question de <RW>Physique</RW>, cela s'appelle bâiller. Retirons-nous, aussi bien en voilà assez pour la premiere fois. Demain nous reviendrons icy, vous avec vos Systêmes, & moi avec mon Ignorance.</P018>
chunks.target_manual: <P012>'Tis pleasant enough, says the Marchioness, to imagin all this you tell me; but if I saw it all from an height, I should wish to have the liberty to hasten or stop the motion of the Earth, according as the Objects pleas'd or displeas'd me; and, I assure you, I should presently turn away those that trouble their Heads with Policy, or eat their Enemies; but for some others I should have a curiosity; particularly for those fair Circassians, they have a custom which methinks is very particular. 'Tis, says I, because they are so fair that their Husbands find in their favours a superfluity, which they allow to strangers. Then the Women of this Country, says the Marchioness, are very ugly, compared with them, for the Husbands here give no liberty at all. That's the reason, says I, they take more, whereas-Hold your peace, says she, I'le talk no more follies; besides I have a serious difficulty come in my head, If the Earth turn, we change Air every moment, and breath that of another Contry. Not at all, Madam, says I, the Air which surrounds the Earth extends but to a certain height, it may be twenty leagues or so, and it follows and turns along with us. You have a thousand times seen the Work of a Silkworm, or those Cods of Silk which those little Animals work with so much Art for their own Prison, they are of a close wrought Silk, but are covered with a certain Down very light and loose. Just so the Earth. which is solid enough, is cover'd from the surface about twenty leagues high at most, with a kind of Down, which is the Air; This and all the other Cod of the Silkworm turns at the same time. Beyond the Air is the Celestial matter incomparably more pure, more subtil, and likewise more in motion than it. You give me, said the Marchioness, Idea's of the Earth contemptible enough; is it then upon this shell of a Silkworm that we labour and toil, and fight, and make such a noise on all hands as we do? 'Tis even so, said I, and in the mean time Nature that takes no notice of those little tle particular motions, carrys us altogether with one general movement, and sports her self with the lit-Ball. To me, says she, it seems something ridiculous to be seated upon a thing that turns? and torment ones self so much; but the mischief is, we are not fully assur'd that we turn; for to tell you truth, notwithstanding all those precautions you have us'd, that a man should not perceive the motion of the Earth, I am still very doubtful. Is it possible it should not be discover'd by some little mark or other? The most natural motions, said I, and the most ordinary, are those which are least perceiv'd, and this is true even in Morality it self. The motion of Self-love is so natural to us, that most commonly we are not at all sensible of it, and think that we are acted by some other principle. Ah! says she, when there's a Question in <NCE>Natural Philosophy</NCE>, you begin to moralize, and that's call'd Bantring. Let us now retire, for this is enough for once. To morrow we'l come here again, you with your Systems, and I with my Ignorance.</P012>
source_segments: qu'il se fait de si grands Travaux, de si grandes Guerres, & qu'il règne de tous côtés une si grande agitation.
target_segments: that we labour and toil, and fight, and make such a noise on all hands as we do?
explanations: The French phrase "ne relâchent rien" (literally "release nothing"), referring to what husbands concede regarding their wives' favors, is general. The translation "give no liberty at all" explicitly defines this "nothing" as a complete lack of "liberty," thereby specifying the nature of the restriction that was implied by the context of the discussion about marital allowances and Circassian customs.

The French "ces Coques" (these cocoons), used after mentioning "Ver à soye" (silkworm), implicitly refers to objects made of silk. The translation "those Cods of Silk" makes the material "Silk" explicit by adding "of Silk," thus adding clarifying information about the composition of the cocoons that was strongly implied but not overtly stated in the original.

The French text uses impersonal constructions ("il se fait" - it is done/made; "il règne" - there reigns) to describe human activities like "grands Travaux" (great Works) and "grandes Guerres" (great Wars), and societal commotion ("si grande agitation"). Human agency is implied. The translation shifts to the first-person plural active voice: "that we labour and toil, and fight, and make such a noise... as we do?" This makes the human agents explicit ("we"), altering the original's more detached, observational tone by directly foregrounding human involvement and responsibility.

The French term "Physique," in the 17th-century context of Fontenelle's work, referred to the broader study of nature then known as "Natural Philosophy," not solely the modern, more specialized field of physics. The translation "in Natural Philosophy" explicitly uses this historically accurate and broader term, thereby clarifying for the English reader the specific, wider field of knowledge being discussed, a nuance that was only implied by the historical context of the word "Physique" in the source text.

chunks.source_manual: <P019>En retournant au Château je luy dis pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes, qu'il y en avoit un troisiéme inventé par Tycho Brahé qui, voulant absolument que la Terre fût immobile, la plaçoit au centre du Monde, & faisoit tourner autour d'elle le Soleil, autour duquel tournoient toutes les autres Planètes, parce que depuis les nouvelles Découvertes, il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planètes autour de la Terre. Mais la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qui a le discernement vif & prompt, jugea qu'il y avoit trop d'affectation à exempter la Terre de tourner autour du Soleil, puisqu'on n'en pouvait pas exempter tant d'autres grands corps; que le Soleil n'étoit plus si propre à tourner autour de la Terre, depuis que toutes les Planètes tournaient autour de luy; que ce systême ne pouvoit être propre tout au plus qu'à soûtenir l'Immobilité de la Terre, quand on avoit bien envie de la soûtenir, & nullement à la persuader; & enfin il fut résolu que nous nous en tiendrions à celuy de Copernic, qui est plus uniforme & plus riant, & n'a aucun mélange de préjugé. En effet la simplicité dont il est, vous persuade, & sa hardiesse vous fait plaisir.</P019>
chunks.target_manual: <P013>In our return to the Castle, I told her, to carry on the business of Systems, that there was a third sort invented by Tycho Brahe, who being absolutely of opinion that the Earth was immovable, plac'd it in the Center of the World, and made the Sun turn about it, and all the Planets about the Sun; because since the new Discoveries, there was no way left to make the Planets turn about the Earth. But the Marchioness, who is of a quick and lively Judgment, was of opinion that it was too much Affectation to exempt the Earth from turning about the Sun, since so many other great Bodies could not be exempted; That it was not so proper for the Sun to turn about the Earth, since all the Planets turn'd about him. That that System was at best only propet to maintain the Immobility of the Earth, when any one had a mind to maintain it, but not at all to persuade it. In fine, we resolv'd to hold to that of Copernicus, which is more uniform, and more delightful, and has no mixture of prejudice. In effect the Simplicity of it persuades, and the Boldness delights.</P013>
source_segments: pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes
il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planètes autour de la Terre
target_segments: to carry on the business of Systems
there was no way left to make the Planets turn about the Earth
explanations: The French phrase "pour épuiser la matiere des Systêmes" primarily means to thoroughly cover or exhaust the subject of Systems. The English translation "to carry on the business of Systems" makes the implied methodical nature of this discussion more explicit by framing it as a "business." This term suggests a defined task or formal undertaking, adding a specific characterization to the activity that is present only implicitly in the original's focus on comprehensiveness.

The French phrase "il n'y avoit pas moyen de faire tourner les Planètes autour de la Terre" (there was no way/means to make the Planets turn around the Earth), stated in the context of "depuis les nouvelles Découvertes" (since the new Discoveries), indicates an impossibility. The English translation "there was no way left to make the Planets turn about the Earth" makes explicit the implied consequence of these discoveries: that previous possibilities or ways of understanding were eliminated. The addition of "left" spells out that the current lack of a "way" is the result of a reduction from a prior state, clarifying a relationship (the impact of the discoveries) that is less directly stated in the French.

chunks.source_manual: <P020>SECOND SOIR. Que la Lune est une Terre habitée.</P020>
chunks.target_manual: <P014>THE Second Evening.</P014>

chunks.source_manual: <P021>Le lendemain au matin dès que l'on pût entrer dans l'Appartement de la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, j'envoyai savoir de ses nouvelles, & lui demander si elle avoit pû dormir en tournant. Elle me fit répondre qu'elle etoit déjà toute accoûtumée à cette allûre de la Terre, & qu'elle avoit passé la nuit aussi tranquillement qu'auroit pû faire Copernic lui-même. Quelque temps après il vint chez elle du monde qui y demeura jusqu'au soir, selon l'ennuyeuse coutume de la Campagne. Encore leur fut-on bien obligé, car la Campagne leur donnoit aussi le droit de pousser leur visite jusqu'au lendemain, s'ils eussent voulu, & ils eurent l'honnêteté de ne le pas faire. Ainsi la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> & moi nous nous retrouvâmes libres le Soir. Nous allâmes encore dans le Parc, & la conversation ne manqua pas de tourner aussitôt sur nos Sistêmes. Elle les avoit si bien conceus, qu'elle dédaigna d'en parler une seconde fois, & elle voulut que je la menasse a quelque chose de nouveau. Et bien donc, luy dis-je, puisque le Soleil, qui est présentement immobile, a cessé d'être Planète, & que la Terre qui se meut autour de lui, a commencé d'en être une, vous ne serez pas si surprise d'entendre dire que la Lune est une Terre comme celle-cy, & qu'apparemment elle est habitée. Je n'ay pourtant jamais oüy parler de la Lune habitée, dit-elle, que comme d'une <IIM>folie & d'une vision</IIM>. C'en est peut-être une aussi, répondis-je. Je ne prens parti dans ces choses-là que comme on en prend dans les Guerres Civiles, où l'incertitude de ce qui peut arriver, fait qu'on entretient toûjours des <IIM>intelligences</IIM> dans le party opposé, & <IIM>qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mêmes</IIM>. Pour moi, quoyque je voye la Lune habitée, je ne laisse pas de vivre civilement avec ceux qui ne le croyent pas, <SC>—</SC> & je me tiens toujours en état de me pouvoir ranger à leur opinion avec honneur, si elle avoit le dessus; mais en attendant qu'ils ayent sur nous quelque avantage considérable, voyci ce qui m'a mis du côté des Habitans de la Lune.</P021>
chunks.target_manual: <P015>NExt Morning, as soon as the Marchioness could be seen, I sent to know how she did, and to ask her if she could sleep well turning? She sent me word, that she was so well accustomed to that sort of motion of the Earth, that she pass'd the night as quietly as Copernicus himself could have done. Soon after she had Company came to her, who, according to the troublesome Custome in the Country, stay'd with her till Evening; and they were obliging in that too; for by the Custom in the Country they had a right to continue their Visits till next morning if they pleas'd; but they were so honest as to be gone. So that the Marchioness and I found our selves at liberty in the Evening. We took our Walk again into the Park, and our Conversation fail'd not to return presently to our Systems. She had apprehended them so well, that she disdain'd to discourse of them a second time, but would needs have me lead her to some new matter.</P015> <P016>Well then, said I, since the Sun, that is now immovable, is no more a Planet, and that the Earth, that moves about him, has begun to be one, you will not be so surpriz'd to hear that the Moon is an Earth like this, and that apparently she is inhabited. Truly, says she, I never yet heard speak of the Moon's being inhabited, but only as a Folly and a Vision. Possibly 'tis such, said I. I do not ingage in things of that nature, but as men ingage in a Civil War, where the incertainty of the event makes them still hold inteligence with the opposite Party, and maintain an Intrigue with the very Enemy. For my part, though I should see the Moon inhabited, yet I would still live civilly with those that do not believe it, and I preserve my self in such a condition, that I may with Honour subscribe to their Opinion, if it prevail. But in the mean while, till they get some considerable advantages over us, see what it is has drawn me to side with the Inhabitants of the Moon.</P016>
source_segments: qu'on a des ménagemens avec ses Ennemis mêmes
target_segments: that sort of motion of the Earth
and maintain an Intrigue with the very Enemy
explanations: The French "cette allûre de la Terre" uses "allûre" (gait, pace, characteristic way of moving) to refer to the Earth's recently discussed turning. The translation "that sort of motion of the Earth" makes explicit that "allûre" here signifies a *category* or *type* of movement. This clarifies the somewhat figurative French term by directly classifying it as a "sort of motion," thus making the reference to a physical phenomenon more direct for the reader.

The French "de ne le pas faire" (literally, "not to do it") refers implicitly to the guests not extending their visit, an option mentioned in the preceding clause. The translation "as to be gone" makes the outcome of their politeness explicit by stating the positive action the visitors took (they left), rather than merely negating the potential action of overstaying. This spells out the unstated consequence of their "honnêteté."

The French "ménagemens" implies tactful, cautious, or diplomatic dealings, particularly in a difficult context like a civil war. The translation "maintain an Intrigue" makes explicit a specific, more conspiratorial interpretation by using the word "Intrigue," which denotes secret scheming or plotting. This narrows the broader, more neutral meaning of "ménagemens" to a specific type of clandestine activity, which was only one possible unstated implication of the source term.

chunks.source_manual: <P022>Suposons qu'il n'y ait jamais eu nul commerce entre <NCE>Paris & Saint-Denis</NCE>, & qu'un Bourgeois de Paris, qui ne sera jamais sorty de sa Ville, soit sur les Tours de <NCE>Notre Dame</NCE>, & voye <NCE>Saint-Denis</NCE> de loin; on luy demandera s'il croit que <NCE>Saint-Denis</NCE> soit habité <SC>comme Paris</SC>. Il répondra hardiment que non; car, dira- t-il, je vois bien les Habitans de Paris, mais ceux de Saint-Denis je ne les voy point, & on n'en a jamais entendu parler. Il y aura quelqu'un qui luy representera qu'à la vérité quand on est sur les <NCE>Tours de Notre-Dame</NCE>, on ne voit pas les Habitans de Saint-Denis, mais que l'éloignement en est cause; que tout ce qu'on peut voir de Saint-Denis ressemble fort à Paris, que Saint Denis a des Clochers, des Maisons, des Murailles, & qu'il pourrait bien encore ressembler à Paris pour ce qui est d'être habité. Tout cela ne gagnera rien sur mon Bourgeois, il s'obstinera toûjours à soûtenir que Saint-Denis n'est point habité, puisqu'il n'y voit personne. Notre Saint-Denis c'est la Lune, & chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris, qui n'est jamais sorty de sa Ville.</P022>
chunks.target_manual: <P017>Let us suppose that there was never any Commerce between Paris and St. Denis (a Town about three miles from Paris) and that a Burgess of Paris, who never stirr'd out of the Town, should from the top of Nostre Dame see Saint Denis at a distance, the question is put him, whether he believes that Saint Denis is inhabited as Paris is or not, he'l confidently say no; for, says he, I see plainly the Inhabitants of Paris, but those of Saint Denis I do not see at all, nor ever heard speak of them. Some standerby may tell him, that 'tis true indeed that from the top of Nostre Dame the Inhabitants of Saint Denis are not seen, but that 'tis the distance is the cause, that all that can be seen of Saint Denis is very like Paris, that Saint Denis has Steeples, and Houses and Walls, and possibly may likewise resemble Paris in being inhabited, all this will not prevail with my honest Burgess, he's still obstinate that Saint Denis cannot be inhabited, because he sees not a man in it. Our Saint Denis is the Moon, and every one of us is just such a Burgess of Paris that never stirr'd out of the Town.</P017>
target_segments: St. Denis (a Town about three miles from Paris)
just such a Burgess of Paris
explanations: The original French text relies on the contemporary reader's implicit local knowledge of Saint-Denis as a town near Paris. The translator makes this geographical and contextual information explicit by adding the parenthetical clarification "(a Town about three miles from Paris)", which is crucial for an English-speaking audience of the time (and later) to grasp the full meaning of the analogy being made between the Parisian's view of St. Denis and humanity's view of the Moon.

The French "mon Bourgeois" (my citizen/burgess) is used by Fontenelle to refer to the hypothetical Parisian. The possessive "mon" combined with the context of the citizen's naivety and stubbornness can imply a certain archetype – a typical, perhaps simple or unworldly, individual. The translator's addition of "honest" (likely in an archaic sense meaning 'simple', 'ordinary', or 'unpretentious', rather than 'truthful') makes this implied characteristic of the figure more explicit, fleshing out the archetypal nature of the "Bourgeois" for the English reader.

The French "ce Bourgeois de Paris" (this/that Burgess of Paris), found in the phrase "chacun de nous est ce Bourgeois de Paris", refers to the specific, anecdotally described citizen as an exemplar of limited perspective. The English translation "just such a Burgess of Paris" (in "every one of us is just such a Burgess of Paris") makes more explicit the nature of the identification: it's not merely being like that specific individual, but rather being individuals of precisely the same kind or type, characterized by the same defined ignorance and parochialism. The phrase "just such a" spells out this typological comparison and the exactness of the match in characteristics, which is implied by "ce" in its anaphoric, exemplary function in the French.

chunks.source_manual: <P023>Ah! interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous nous faites tort, nous ne sommes point si sots que votre Bourgeois. Puis qu'il voit que Saint-Denis est tout fait comme Paris, il faut qu'il ait perdu la raison pour ne le pas croire habité; mais la Lune n'est point du tout faite comme la Terre. Prenez garde, Madame, repris-je, car s'il faut que la Lune ressemble en tout à la Terre, vous voilà dans l'obligation de croire la Lune habitée. J'avoüe, répondit-elle, qu'il n'y aura pas moyen de s'en dispenser, & je vous vois un air de confiance qui me fait déjà peur. Les deux mouvements de la Terre, dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée, me <IIM>rendent timide sur tout le reste</IIM>; mais pourtant seroit-il bien possible que la Terre fût lumineuse comme la Lune? Car il faut cela pour leur ressemblance. Hélas! Madame, répliquay-je, être lumineux n'est pas si grand-chose que vous pensez. Il n'y a que le Soleil en qui cela soit une qualité considérable. Il est lumineux par luy- même, & en vertu d'une nature particulière qu'il a; mais les Planètes n'éclairent que parce qu'elles sont éclairées de luy. Il envoye sa lumière à la Lune, elle nous la renvoye, & il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumière du Soleil; il n'y a pas plus loin de la Terre à la Lune, que de la Lune à la Terre.</P023>
chunks.target_manual: <P018>Oh! said the Marchioness, you do us wrong, we are not so dull as your Burgess; he that sees Saint Denis wholly made like Paris, must needs have lost his Reason, not to believe that 'tis inhabited; but the Moon is not at all made like the Earth. Have a care, Madam, said I, for if I prove that the Moon must resemble the Earth, you are then downright oblig'd to believe that the Moon is inhabited. I acknowledge, says she, there will be no way to avoid it; and I observe in your looks an air of confidence that makes me half afraid. The two motions of the Earth, of which I shall never make any doubt, make me timorous in all the rest; but however, is it possible that the Earth should be luminous as the Moon is? for that must be to make up the resemblance. Alas, Madam, said I, to be luminous is not so a great matter as you imagine; there is only the Sun in which that quality is considerable; he is luminous in himself, by vertue of a nature peculiar to him, but the Planets give no Light, but as they are inlighten'd by him. He sends his Light to the Moon, she returns it to us, and it must needs be likewise, that the Earth sends the Light of the Sun to the Moon; for 'tis no farther from the Earth to the Moon, than from the Moon to the Earth.</P018>
source_segments: s'il faut que la Lune ressemble en tout à la Terre
dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée
target_segments: if I prove that the Moon must resemble the Earth
of which I shall never make any doubt
explanations: The original French "s'il faut que..." (if it is necessary that... / if it must be that...) posits a hypothetical condition impersonally. The English translation "if I prove that..." explicitly attributes the agency of establishing this condition to the speaker (the philosopher), making his role as demonstrator explicit within this specific clause. While the philosopher's overall aim is to prove, the French phrasing here focuses on the logical necessity of the resemblance itself, not his act of proving it at this specific point in the argument.

The French "qui me fait déjà peur" (which already makes me afraid/which is already frightening me) suggests an incipient or early stage of fear, with "déjà" (already) indicating it has just begun. The English "half afraid" makes this nuance explicit by quantifying the degree of fear, clarifying that it is not yet complete or overwhelming. This is a specific interpretation of the implication of "déjà" in this context.

The French "dont je ne me fusse jamais doutée" (of which I would never have suspected/doubted) uses a subjunctive mood to express the Marquise's past state of unawareness and surprise regarding the new information about Earth's motions. The English translation "of which I shall never make any doubt" shifts this to an explicit statement of her current firm conviction and future certainty regarding these motions. This spells out the implied consequence of her having learned and accepted the information, which was only suggested by her subsequent timidity in the original.

The French "pour leur ressemblance" (for their resemblance), in the context of "Car il faut cela pour leur ressemblance" (For that is necessary for their resemblance), indicates that the Earth being luminous is a requirement for the likeness between Earth and Moon. The English translation "to make up the resemblance" makes explicit the *manner* in which luminosity is necessary: by constituting or forming an essential part of that resemblance. It clarifies that luminosity is a component required to complete the likeness, a specific functional role that "pour" (for) implies more generally.

The French adverb "aussi" (also, too), in the phrase "il faut que la Terre renvoye aussi à la Lune la lumière du Soleil" (it is necessary that the Earth also send back to the Moon the Sun's light), signifies that the Earth performs the action of reflecting sunlight in addition to the Moon (which was previously discussed as reflecting light to Earth). The English adverb "likewise" makes more explicit the parallel nature or similar manner of this action, emphasizing that the Earth acts in a similar way to the Moon. This spells out a specific relational aspect of similarity that "aussi" allows for but does not state as directly.

chunks.source_manual: <P024>Mais, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, la Terre est-elle aussi propre que la Lune à renvoyer la lumiere du Soleil? Je vous vois toûjours, pour la Lune, repris-je, un reste d'estime dont vous ne sauriez vous défaire. La lumiere est composée de petites balles qui bondissent sur ce qui est solide <UP></UP>, & retournent d'un autre côté, au lieu qu'elles passent au travers de ce qui leur presente des ouvertures en ligne droite, comme l'air ou le verre. Ainsi ce qui fait que la Lune nous éclaire, c'est qu'elle est un Corps dur & solide, qui nous renvoye ces petites balles. Or je croy que vous ne contesterez pas à la Terre cette même dureté e& cette même solidité. Admirez donc ce que c'est que d'être posté avantageusement. Parce que la Lune est éloignée de nous, nous ne la voyons que comme un Corps lumineux, & nous ignorons que ce soit une grosse masse, toute semblable à la Terre. <IIM>Au contraire,</IIM> parce que la Terre a le malheur que nous la voyons de trop prés, elle ne nous paroît qu'une grosse masse, propre seulement à fournir de la pâture aux Animaux, & nous ne nous apercevons pas qu'elle est lumineuse, faute de nous pouvoir mettre à quelque distance d'elle. Cela va de la même maniere, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que quand nous sommes frapés de l'éclat des Conditions; élevées au-dessus des nôtres, & que nous ne voyons pas, qu'au fond elles se ressemblent toutes extrêmement.</P024> <P025>C'est la même chose, répondis-je. Nous voulons juger de tout, & nous sommes toûjours dans un mauvais point de veüe. Nous voulons juger de nous, nous en sommes trop près; nous voulons juger des autres, nous en sommes trop loin. Qui serait entre la Lune & la Terre, ce seroit la vraye place pour les bien voir. Il faudroit être simplement spectateur du Monde, & non pas Habitant. Je ne me consoleray jamais, dit-elle, de l'injustice que nous faisons à la Terre, & de la préoccupation trop favorable où nous sommes pour la Lune, si vous ne m'assurez que les Gens de la Lune ne connaissent pas mieux leurs avantages que nous connoissons les nôtres, & qu'ils prennent notre Terre pour un Astre, sans savoir que leur habitation en est un aussi. Pour cela, repris-je, je vous le garantis. Nous leur paraissons faire assez regulièrement nos fonctions d'Astres. Il est vray qu'ils ne nous voyent pas décrire un Cercle autour d'eux; mais il n'importe, voicy ce que c'est. La moitié de la Lune qui se trouva tournée vers nous au commencement du Monde, y a toûjours eté tournée depuis; elle ne nous présente jamais que ces yeux, cette bouche, & le reste de ce visage que notre imagination luy compose sur le fondement des tâches qu'elle nous montre. Si l'autre moitié opposée se presentoit à nous, d'autres tâches differemment arrangées, nous feroient sans doute imaginer quelque autre figure. Ce n'est pas que la Lune ne tourne sur elle-même, elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois; mais lors qu'elle fait une partie de ce tremblement <RW></RW>, & de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.</P025>
chunks.target_manual: <P019>But, says the Marchioness, is the Earth as proper as the Moon to reflect the Light of the Sun? I observe, said I, that you have still a good thought for the Moon, which you cannot part with. The Light is composed of little Balls, that rebound from any thing that is solid, whereas they pass in a straight line through any thing that opens to them, as the Air, or Glass. So that hence it is that the Moon gives us Light, because she is a hard solid body that reflects those little Balls upon us. Now I believe you will not at all contest the solidity of the Earth. Admire then what it is to be advantagiously plac'd. The Moon being so far distant from us, we only behold it as a luminous body, and know not that 'tis a great mass like the Earth. On the contrary, because the Earth has the ill luck to be seen by us near at hand, she appears to us a great mass fit for nothing but to feed Cattel, and cannot discern that she is luminous, because we cannot set our selves at distance enough from her. Just so, said she, we are dazl'd with the lustre of Conditions more elevated than our own, and never discern that in the bottom they are extremely alike.</P019> <P020>'Tis even so, said I we would judge of all, but are still ill placed to take our view; in judging of our selves we are too near, and in judging of others too far off. The middle place between the Moon and the Earth is the best to take a right prospect of both; and better it would be, to be simply a Spectator of the World than an Inhabitant. I shall never be comforted, says she, for the Injustice we do the Earth, and our too much partiality to the Moon, unless you assure me that the people of the Moon, have no more knowledge of their Advantages than we have of ours, and that they take our Earth for a Star, without knowing that their own Habitation is so likewise. I'le warrant you for that, said I, we appear to them to perform our function of a Star regularly enough: 'tis true they do not see us describe a Circle about them; but 'tis no matter, the thing is this; The half of the Moon which was turn'd towards us at the beginning of the World, has continued so ever since, she still shews the same Eyes, the same Mouth, and all the rest of the Face, which those Spots we discern in her, frame in our Imagination; if we saw the other half, other kind of Spots, in different posture, would doubtless create in our Imagination other kind of Figures. 'Tis not that the Moon does not turn about her self, 'tis certain she turns in just so much time as she turns about the Earth, that is, in a month. But when she has made one part of that turn about her self, and that she ought to hide, for example, one Cheek of that pretended Face from us, and appear some other thing, she makes the like part of her Circle about the Earth, and putting her self in a new point of sight, shews us still the same Cheek. So that the Moon, that in respect of the Sun and other Stars, turns about her self, in respect of us turns not all. She sees them all rise and set in the space of fifteen days, but our Earth she sees daily hanging in the same place of Heaven. This seeming Immobility agrees not well with a body which ought to pass for a Star; but 'tis true likewise that she her self is not perfect. The Moon has a certain wavering motion <RW>(motus libratorius)</RW> which is the cause that a little corner of her Face is sometimes hid, and a little corner of the opposite side appears. Now I'le undertake, that she imputes that wavering to us, and imagines that we have a movement to and fro in the Heavens like a Pendulum.</P020>
source_segments: elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois;
& de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient.
target_segments: to take a right prospect of both

But when she has made one part of that turn about her self, and that she ought to hide, for example, one Cheek of an that pretended Face from us, and appear some other thing, she makes the like part of her Circle about the Earth, and putting her self in a new point of sight, shews us still the same Cheek. So that the Moon, that in respect of the Sun and other Stars, turns about her self, in respect of us turns not all. She sees them all rise and set in the space of fifteen days, but our Earth she sees daily hanging in the same place of Heaven. This seeming Immobility agrees not well with a body which ought to pass for a Star; but 'tis true likewise that she her self is not perfect.
a certain wavering motion (motus libratorius) which is the cause that a little corner of her Face is sometimes hid, and a little corner of the opposite side appears
Now I'le undertake, that she imputes that wavering to us, and imagines that we have a movement to and fro in the Heavens like a Pendulum.
explanations: The French 'les bien voir' (to see them well) is general. The English translation 'to take a right prospect of both' makes explicit that 'les' (them) refers to 'both' the Moon and the Earth (which were the subject of the preceding discussion). Additionally, 'take a right prospect' specifies a more considered or surveyed manner of viewing, which is an elaboration of the simpler 'bien voir'.

The French 'elle y tourne' (it turns there/on itself) is a declarative statement of fact regarding the Moon's rotation. The English translation adds ''tis certain' before 'she turns', explicitly emphasizing the certainty of this fact, which was only implicitly asserted by the declarative mood in the French.

The French source text states the fact of the Moon's synchronous rotation ('elle y tourne en autant de temps qu'autour de la Terre, c'est à dire, en un mois;'). The English translation then inserts this extensive passage. This addition explicitly details the mechanics of how synchronous rotation results in the same lunar face being visible from Earth, discusses the relativity of the Moon's rotation from different perspectives (Sun/stars vs. Earth), describes what hypothetical Moon inhabitants would observe regarding other stars and the Earth, and comments on the Moon's nature. This entire passage spells out complex astronomical consequences and observational details that are only implicitly derivable from Fontenelle's concise statement at this point.

The French 'ce tremblement' (this trembling/wavering) is a concise reference to the phenomenon of lunar libration. The English translation significantly explicates this by identifying it as 'a certain wavering motion,' providing the contemporary scientific Latin term '(motus libratorius),' and then clearly explaining its visual consequence: 'which is the cause that a little corner of her Face is sometimes hid, and a little corner of the opposite side appears.' This added descriptive and explanatory detail was entirely implicit in the original French term.

The French phrase '& de s'imaginer que nous avons dans le Ciel comme un mouvement de Pendule qui va & vient' describes the Lunarians' perception ('and [for them] to imagine that we have in the Sky a pendulum-like movement...'). The English translation prefaces this with 'Now I'le undertake,' adding the narrator's explicit assurance. More significantly, it inserts 'that she imputes that wavering to us,' which explicitly states that the Moon's libration (the 'wavering motion' previously explained by the translator) is the cause of the Lunarians' misperception of Earth's movement. This spells out a causal relationship and a layer of narrative assertion not present in the more direct French.

chunks.source_manual: <P026>Toutes ces Planètes, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, sont faites comme nous, qui rejetons toûjours sur les autres ce qui est en nous-mêmes. La Terre dit: Ce n'est pas moy qui tourne, c'est le Soleil. La Lune dit, _Ce n'est pas moy qui tremble, c'est la Terre. Il y a bien de l'erreur par tout. Je ne vous conseille pas d'entreprendre d'y rien réformer, répondis-je, il vaut mieux que vous acheviez de vous convaincre de l'entiere ressemblance de la Terre & de la Lune. Représentez-vous ces deux grandes Boules suspendües dans les Cieux. Vous savez que le Soleil éclaire toûjours une moitié des Corps qui sont ronds, & que l'autre moitié est dans l'ombre. Il y a donc toûjours une moitié, tant de la Terre que de la Lune, qui est éclairée du Soleil, c'est à dire, qui a le jour, & une autre moitié qui est dans la nuit. Remarquez d'ailleurs que comme une Balle a moins de force & de vitesse après qu'elle a été donner contre une muraille qui l'a renvoyée d'un autre côté, de même la lumière s'affoiblit lors qu'elle a été réfléchie par quelque Corps. Cette lumière blanchâtre qui nous vient de la Lune, est la lumière même du Soleil, mais elle ne peut venir de la Lune à nous que par une réflexion. Elle a donc beaucoup perdu de la force & de la vivacité qu'elle avoit lorsqu'elle étoit receüe directement sur la Lune, & cette lumière éclatante que nous recevons du Soleil & que la Terre reflechit sur la Lune, ne doit plus être qu'une lumiere blanchâtre quand elle y est arrivée. Ainsi ce qui nous paroit lumineux dans la Lune, & qui nous éclaire pendant nos nuits, ce sont des parties de la Lune qui ont le jour; & les parties de la Terre qui ont le jour lors qu'elles sont tournées vers les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit les éclairent aussi. Tout dépend de la manière dont la Lune & la Terre se regardent. Dans les premiers jours du mois que l'on ne voit pas la Lune, c'est qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & qu'elle marche de jour avec le Soleil. Il faut necessairement que toute sa moitié qui a le jour, soit tournée vers le Soleil, & que toute sa moitié qui a la nuit, soit tournée vers nous. Nous n'avons garde de voir cette moitié qui n'a aucune lumière pour se faire voir. Mais cette moitié de la Lune qui a la nuit, étant tournée vers la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, nous voit sans être veüe, & nous voit sous la même figure que nous voyons la Pleine Lune. C'est alors pour les Gens de la Lune Pleine Terre, s'il est permis de parler ainsi. Ensuite la Lune qui avance sur son Cercle d'un mois, se dégage de dessous le Soleil, & commence à tourner vers nous un petit coin de sa moitié éclairée, & voilà le Croissant. Alors aussi les parties de la Lune qui ont la nuit commencent à ne plus voir toute la moitié de la Terre qui a le jour, & nous sommes en Décours pour elles.</P026>
chunks.target_manual: <P021>All these Planets, says the Marchioness, I find are made like us, who are still charging others with what is in our selves; the Earth says, 'Tis not I that turn, 'tis the Sun: The Moon says, 'Tis not I that waver, 'tis the Earth: there's faults enough every where. I would not advise you, said I, to attempt a Reformation: 'Tis better that you fully convince your self of the perfect resemblance of the Earth and Moon. Represent to your self those two great Bouls hanging in the Heavens. You know that the Sun always enlightens one half of a Spherical body, and that the other half is in the Shadow. Then the Sun daily enlightens one half both of the Earth and the Moon, viz. in one half 'tis day, in the other night. Observe moreover, that as a Ball loses its force when reverberated from a Wall, so likewise the light grows weak when reflected from another body. That pale Light which we receive from the Moon, is the very Light of the Sun, but it cannot come to us but by Reflection. It must therefore lose much of the force and vivacity it had when it fell directly upon the Moon. So that glittering Light which we receive directly from the Sun, and is reflected from the Earth to the Moon, must needs be but a pale Light when it reaches thither. So that which appears to us luminous in the Moon, and which enlightens us in our nights, is the parts of the Moon where it is then day, and the parts of the Earth where it is day being turn'd towards the parts of the Moon where it is night, inlightens them likewise; all depends upon the manner of the Moon and Earths regarding one another. In the first days of a month, when the Moon is not seen, she is then between the Sun and us, and moves by day along with the Sun. It must needs be, that the half of her where it is day is turn'd toward the Sun, and her other half that is benighted is turn'd towards us. We do not look to see that half that has no Light to shew it self, but that half of the Moon that is benighted being turn'd toward the half of the Earth where it is day, sees us without being seen, and sees us in the same figure as we see the full Moon. 'Tis then, with the Inhabitants of the Moon, full Earth, if I may be permitted the expression. Afterward the Moon, which advances in her monthly Circle, disingages from under the Sun, and begins to shew us a little corner of her inlighten'd half; and that's the Crescent: and then likewise the parts of the Moon that are benighted begin not to see all the half of the Earth that is inlighten'd, and we are running from them.</P021>
source_segments: nous sommes en Décours pour elles.
target_segments: I find are made like us
and we are running from them.
explanations: The addition of 'I find' explicitly states the Marquise's subjective process of realization, whereas the French 'sont faites comme nous' (are made like us) presents it as a more direct observation. This makes her internal thought process and her act of concluding this more overt.

The French 'd'y rien réformer' (to reform anything there) is general. The English 'to attempt a Reformation,' with capitalization, deliberately evokes the idea of a significant, perhaps historical or societal-scale reform, potentially alluding to contemporary British concerns about religious 'Reformation'. This makes the nature and gravity of the 'reform' more explicit and specific than the general French term.

The French 'des Corps qui sont ronds' (of bodies that are round) is translated to the more scientifically precise 'of a Spherical body.' 'Spherical' explicitly defines the three-dimensional geometric shape, clarifying an aspect that, while implied by context for celestial bodies, is not as unequivocally stated by 'ronds' (round), which could also mean circular.

The French 'toûjours' (always), in the phrase 'le Soleil éclaire toûjours une moitié' (the Sun always enlightens one half), emphasizes constancy. The English 'daily' in 'the Sun daily enlightens one half' makes explicit a recurring temporal cycle (the day/night cycle) for this constant illumination, a periodicity implied by the context of day and night but not directly stated by 'toûjours,' which focuses on the continuous state.

The French 'les Gens de la Lune' (the People of the Moon) uses the general term 'Gens' (people). The English 'the Inhabitants of the Moon' explicitly defines these people by their specific relationship to the Moon—as its residents—thus clarifying their status, which was only implied by the general term in French.

The French 'nous sommes en Décours pour elles.' (literally, 'we are in waning phase for them.') describes a state of appearance from the perspective of the Moon's inhabitants. The English 'and we are running from them.' re-interprets this by positing an active, metaphorical movement ('running from') as the cause or dynamic behind the visual phenomenon of waning. This makes an interpreted causal or dynamic relationship explicit that was unstated in the descriptive French astronomical term.

The French 'tremble' (tremble, shake) describes a general motion of instability. The English 'waver' suggests a more specific type of unsteady, oscillating, or flickering movement. By choosing 'waver,' the translator makes explicit a particular characteristic of the perceived instability of the Earth from the Moon, clarifying the nature of the general 'trembling' and potentially adding a nuance of less controlled motion.

chunks.source_manual: <P027>Il n'en faut pas davantage, dit brusquement la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je saurai tout le reste quand il me plaira, je n'ai qu'à y penser un moment, & qu'à promener la Lune sur son Cercle d'un mois. Je vois en gennral que dans la Lune ils ont un mois à rebours du nôtre, & je gage que quand nous avons pleine Lune, c'est que toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune est tournée vers toute la moitié obscure de la Terre; qu'alors ils ne nous voyent point du tout, & qu'ils comtent Nouvelle Terre. Je ne voudrois pas qu'il me fût reproché de m'être fait expliquer tout au long une chose si aisée. Mais les Eclipses, comment vont-elles? Il ne tient qu'à vous de le deviner, répondis-je. Quand la Lune est Nouvelle, qu'elle est entre le Soleil & nous, & que toute sa moitié obscure est tournée vers nous qui avons le jour, vous voyez bien que l'ombre de cette moitié obscure se jette vers nous. Si la Lune est justement sous le Soleil, cette ombre nous le cache, & en même temps noircit une partie de cette moitié lumineuse de la Terre qui etoit vûë par la moitié obscure de la Lune. Voilà donc une Eclipse de Soleil pour nous pendant notre jour, & une Eclipse de Terre pour la Lune pendant sa nuit. Lors que la Lune est pleine, la Terre est entre elle & le Soleil, & toute la moitié obscure de la Terre est tournée vers toute la moitié lumineuse de la Lune. L'ombre de la Terre se jette donc vers la Lune; si elle tombe sur le Corps de la Lune, elle noircit cette moitié lumineuse que nous voyons, & à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour, elle luy dérobe le Soleil. Voilà donc une Eclipse de Lune pour nous pendant notre nuit, & une Eclipse de Soleil pour la Lune pendant le jour dont elle joüissait. Ce qui fait qu'il n'arrive pas des Eclipses toutes les fois que la Lune est entre le Soleil & la Terre, ou la Terre entre le Soleil & la Lune, c'est que souvent ces trois Corps ne sont pas tres exactement rangez en ligne droite, & que par consequent celuy qui devroit faire l'Eclipse, jette son ombre un peu à côté de celuy qui en devroit être couvert.</P027>
chunks.target_manual: <P022>'Tis enough, said the Marchioness briskly, I shall know all the rest when I please, I need but think on it a moment and walk the Moon about her monthly Circuit. I see in general that in the Moon they have a month reverse to ours, and I'le hold a Wager, that when 'tis full Moon with us, 'tis the inlighten'd half of the Moon turn'd towards the obscure part of the Earth, and 'tis then they see us not at all, and count it New Earth. I would not be reproch'd to have requir'd so minute an explication of a thing so easie. But pray how happen the Ecclipses? That, said I, belongs to you to judge. When 'tis New Moon, that she is between us and the Sun, and that all her obscure part is turn'd towards us in our day time; you see well that the Shadow of that obscure half is cast towards us. If the Moon be directly under the Sun, that Shadow hides him from us, and at the same time darkens all that luminous part of the Earth that was seen by the obscure part of the Moon. See there an Eclipse of the Sun for us in our day time, and an Eclipse of the Earth for the Moon in their night. When the Moon is full the Earth is between her and the Sun, and all the obscure half of the Earth is turn'd towards the inlighten'd half of the Moon; The Shadow of the Earth is then cast towards the Moon, and if it fall upon the body of the Moon it darkens that luminous half waich we saw, and hides the Sun from that luminous half in the Moon where it was day. See there an Eclipse of the Moon for us in our night, and an Eclipse of the Sun for the Moon in her day The reason why Eclipses do not happen every time that the Moon is between the Sun and the Earth, or the Earth between the Sun and the Moon, is because those three bodies are not always in a right line one to the other, and by consequence that Body that ought to make the Eclipse casts its Shadow a little on one side of that which should be obscured by it.</P022>
source_segments: vers nous qui avons le jour
target_segments: towards us in our day time
that luminous half in the Moon
in a right line one to the other
that Body that ought to make the Eclipse
explanations: The French "tout au long" (at length, in full detail), describing the manner of explanation, is rendered such that the English specifies the nature of this detail with "minute" (in the phrase "so minute an explication"). This makes explicit that the comprehensiveness would extend to very small, particular details, a quality implied but not directly lexicalized by the general French term for thoroughness.

The French "deviner" (to guess, to divine, or to figure out) is translated as "to judge." In the context of the Marquise's intellectual engagement, "to judge" makes explicit that the expected mental process is one of reasoned deduction based on prior information, rather than mere intuition or guessing, aligning with the Enlightenment emphasis on reason.

The French relative clause "qui avons le jour" (literally "who have the day," meaning "for whom it is daytime") describes "us." The English translation "in our day time" rephrases this as a prepositional phrase indicating a temporal condition, making the circumstance (it being daytime for "us") more explicit and direct.

The French "sa nuit" refers to the Moon's own night ("its night"). The English translation "in their night" explicitly shifts the perspective to that of hypothetical inhabitants of the Moon. This makes explicit the implication of sentient beings experiencing night on the Moon, a core theme of Fontenelle's work concerning the plurality of worlds, which is contextually implied but not directly conveyed by the singular possessive "sa."

The French "cette moitié lumineuse" (this luminous half), in the phrase "à cette moitié lumineuse qui avoit le jour," refers to the Moon's luminous half, which is understood from the immediate context. The English translation renders this as "that luminous half in the Moon," explicitly adding "in the Moon" to specify the location. This addition provides clarifying information that was previously only contextually implied.

The French "rangez en ligne droite" (arranged in a straight line) is translated as "in a right line one to the other." The additional phrase "one to the other" makes explicit the relative alignment and mutual relationship between the three celestial bodies forming the line, a geometric detail that is implied but not overtly spelled out in the more general French expression.

The French demonstrative pronoun "celuy" (that one/the one) in "celuy qui devroit faire l'Eclipse" contextually refers to one of the celestial bodies. The English translation "that Body that ought to make the Eclipse" makes this referent explicit by adding the noun "Body," thereby clarifying the nature of the agent causing the eclipse.

chunks.source_manual: <P028>Je suis fort étonnée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il y ait si peu de mystere aux Eclipses, & que tout le monde n'en devine pas la cause. Ah! vraiment, répondis-je, il y a bien des Peuples qui de la maniere dont ils s'y prennent, ne la devineroient encore de longtemps. Dans toutes les Indes Orientales, on croit que quand le Soleil & la Lune s'éclipsent, c'est qu'un certain Demon qui a les Griffes fort noires, les étend sur ces Astres dont il veut se saisir; & vous voyez pendant ce temps-là les Rivières couvertes de Têtes d'Indiens qui se sont mis dans l'eau jusqu'au cou, parce que c'est une situation tres propre à obtenir du Soleil & de la Lune qu'ils se défendent bien contre le Demon. En Amérique, on etoit persuadé que le Soleil & la Lune etoient fâchéz quand ils s'éclipsoient, & Dieu sait ce qu'on ne faisoit pas pour se raccommoder avec eux. Mais les Grecs qui etoient si raffinez, n'ont-ils pas creu long-temps que la Lune étoit ensorcelée, & que des Magiciennes la faisoient descendre du Ciel pour jeter sur les Herbes une certaine écume malfaisante? Mais nous, n'eûmes-nous pas belle peur il n'y guere plus de trente ans, à une certaine Eclipse de Soleil, qui arriva? Une infinité de Gens ne se tinrent-ils pas enfermez dans des caves, & <IIM>les Philosophes</IIM> <NCE></NCE> qui écrivent pour nous rassurer, n'écrivirent ils pas en vain?</P028>
chunks.target_manual: <P023>I am very much astonished, said the Marchioness, that there should be so little Mystery in Eclipses, and yet all the World so ignorant of their Causes. Ah! said I, there are enough in the World, that as they go to work, will never understand them. The East Indians believe that when the Sun and Moon are in Eclipse, it is a certain Demon that with his black Paws stretch'd out towards those Stars, endeavours to lay hold on them, and you shall see at that time the Rivers cover'd with Heads of Indians, who plunge themselves up to the neck in Water, as the most devout posture, in their opinion, to prevail with the Sun and Moon to protect them from the Paws of the Demon. The Americans think the Sun and Moon are angry with them when they are eclips'd, and God knows what they do not, to reconcile themselves with them. The Greeks, who were so refin'd, did they not believe a long while that the Moon was then inchanted, and that she was brought down from Heaven by Magicians, to cast a malignant froth upon Herbs? And we our selves were we not very fairly frighten'd at an Eclipse of the Sun not above thirty years since? When an infinite number of people shut themselves up in Caves, and the Philosophers that imploy'd their Pens to incourage us, writ in vain.</P023>
source_segments: ne la devineroient encore de longtemps.
target_segments: as the most devout posture, in their opinion
explanations: The French phrase "n'en devine pas la cause" (doesn't guess its cause) implies a lack of knowledge. The English translation "so ignorant of their Causes" makes this underlying state of ignorance explicit, directly stating the condition (ignorance) that leads to not guessing.

The French "ne la devineroient encore de longtemps." (would not guess it [the cause] for a long time yet) implies a prolonged inability to discover the cause. The English "will never understand them." makes this failure to comprehend more absolute by using "never" and makes the scope of understanding explicit ("understand them" – the phenomena themselves or their broader nature, rather than just guessing "it" – the specific singular cause referenced by "la").

The French "c'est une situation tres propre" (it is a very suitable/appropriate situation) is made more explicit by the English translation "as the most devout posture, in their opinion." This addition clarifies the specific nature and subjective reasoning (devotion, their belief) behind the situation's suitability, details which are only implied in the original text's description of the people's actions.

The French "la Lune étoit ensorcelée" (the Moon was bewitched), within the context of discussing eclipses and unusual celestial events, implies this belief was particularly relevant during such specific times. The English translation "the Moon was then inchanted" makes this temporal connection to the specific occurrence of the phenomenon (e.g., eclipse) explicit by adding "then."

The French verb "écrivent" (write) is translated as "imploy'd their Pens." The English phrase explicitly states the means or instrument ("Pens") of writing, information which is only implicitly understood in the general verb "écrivent." This expands the condensed expression by detailing the method of action.

chunks.source_manual: <P029>En vérité, reprit-elle, tout cela est trop honteux pour les hommes, il devrait y avoir un Arrêt du Genre humain, qui défendît qu'on parlât jamais d'Eclipses, de peur que l'on ne conserve la memoire des sotises qui ont été faites ou dites sur ce Chapitre là. Il faudrait donc, répliquai-je, que le même Arrêt abolît la memoire de toutes choses, & défendît qu'on parlât jamais de rien, car je ne sache rien au monde qui ne soit le monument de quelque sotise des hommes.</P029>
chunks.target_manual: <P024>Truly, says she, all this is very much to the shame of Men; there ought to be a general Edict prohibiting, That none should ever speak of an Eclipse, for fear of preserving the memory of those Follies that have been said and done upon that account. Then 'twill be likewise necessary, said I, by the same Edict to abolish the memory of all things, and forbid ever speaking of any thing; for I know nothing in the World that is not a monument of the Folly of mankind.</P024>
explanations: The French 'des sotises' (some follies / follies in general) is translated as 'those Follies'. The use of the demonstrative 'those' makes the reference more specific and explicit, pointing to particular follies assumed to be known or understood from the immediate context of discussing eclipses. The French 'des' is more indefinite, and the English 'those' clarifies that specific, implied follies are being referred to.

The French 'donc' (then, therefore) in 'Il faudrait donc' primarily indicates a logical consequence. The English translation renders this with 'Then' (in 'Then 'twill be likewise necessary') and adds the adverb 'likewise'. This addition of 'likewise' explicitly spells out the analogical or parallel nature of the philosopher's argument—that a broader edict would be necessary in a similar fashion to the one proposed for eclipses. This comparative aspect is only implied by the context in French but made explicit by 'likewise' in English.

The French phrase 'quelque sotise des hommes' (some folly of men, or a certain folly of men) refers to an individual or unspecified instance of foolishness committed by men. The translation 'the Folly of mankind' reifies this into a singular, capitalized, abstract concept ('the Folly') attributed to 'mankind' as a whole. This explicitation elevates the idea from particular acts of folly to a general, inherent characteristic of humanity, thereby intensifying the philosophical statement and making the abstract nature of this human flaw more explicit.

chunks.source_manual: <P030>Dites-moi, je vous prie, une chose, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Ont-ils autant de peur des Eclipses dans la Lune, que nous en avons ici? Il me paraîtroit tout-à-fait burlesque, que les Indiens de ce pays-là se missent à l'eau comme les nôtres; que les Amériquains crussent notre Terre fâchée contre eux; que les Grecs s'imaginassent que nous fussions ensorcelez; que nous allassions gâter leurs Herbes, & qu'enfin nous leur rendissions la consternation qu'ils causent icy-bas. Je n'en doute nullement, répondis-je. Je voudrais bien savoir pourquoy Messieurs de la Lune auroient l'esprit plus fort que nous. De quel droit nous feront-ils peur sans que nous leur en fassions? Je croirois même, ajoûtai-je en riant, que comme un nombre prodigieux d'hommes ont été assez fous, & le sont encore assez pour adorer la Lune, il y a des Gens dans la Lune qui adorent aussi la Terre, & que nous sommes à genoux les uns devant les autres. Aprés cela, dit-elle, <IIM>nous pouvons bien prétendre</IIM> à envoyer des influences à la Lune, & à donner des crises à ses Malades, mais comme il ne faut qu'un peu d'esprit & d'habileté dans les Gens de ce Pays-là, pour détruire tous ces honneurs dont nous nous flattons, j'avoüe que je crains toûjours que nous n'ayons quelque desavantage.</P030>
chunks.target_manual: <P025>Pray tell me one thing, says the Marchioness, are they as much afraid of an Eclipse in the Moon as we are here? It would seem to me a meer Burlesque, that the Indians of that Country should plunge themselves into the Water as ours do, and that the Americans there should think our Earth angry with them, or the Greeks imagine that we are inchanted and go down to spoil their Herbs, or that we should put them in such a consternation as they put us here. I do not at all doubt it, said I, I would very fain know why the Gentlemen of the Moon should have more Wit than we, or what right have they to scare us, more than we have to scare them? And I believe, said I laughing, that as there have been and are an infinite number of Fools that adore the Moon, so there are likewise in the Moon people that adore the Earth, and we are upon our knees one to another: After all this, says she, we may well pretend to send Influences to the Moon, and give the Crises to their Diseases. But as but very little Wit and Ability is sufficient in the people of that Country, to destroy all those Honours we flatter our selves withal; I must confess, I am still afraid we have somewhat the disadvantage.</P025>
source_segments: hommes ont été assez fous, & le sont encore assez
