The translator makes this implied possession and specificity explicit by translating the indefinite 'un Air' into the definite and possessive 'her Air.' This directly spells out the Moon's ownership of the atmosphere.

chunks.source_manual: <P042>Ces deux Airs diferens, repris-je, contribuent à empêcher la communication des deux Planetes. S'il ne tenoit qu'à voler; que savons-nous, comme je vous disois hier, si on ne volera pas fort bien quelque jour? J'avoüe pourtant qu'il n'y a pas beaucoup d'apparence. Le grand éloignement de la Lune à la Terre serait encore une difficulté à surmonter, qui est assurement considerable, mais quand même elle ne s'y rencontreroit pas, quand même les deux Planetes seroient proches, <UP></UP> il ne seroit pas possible de passer de l'Air de l'une dans l'air de l'autre. L'eau est l'air des Poissons, ils ne passent jamais dans l'Air des Oiseaux dans l'air des Poissons; ce n'est pas la distance qui les en empêche, c'est que chacun a pour prison l'air qu'il respire. Nous trouvons que le nôtre est mêlé de vapeurs plus épaisses & plus grossières que celuy de la Lune. A ce compte, un Habitan de la Lune qui seroit arrivé aux confins de notre Monde, se noyeroit dés qu'il entreroit dans notre Air, & nous le verrions tomber mort sur la Terre.</P042>
chunks.target_manual: <P038>Those two different Airs, said I, do much contribute to hinder the Communication of the two Planets. If there were no more than flying in the matter, who knows, as I told you yesterday, but that in time we may fly well enough. Yet I confess there is no great appearance of it, the great distance of the Moon from the Earth would be one difficulty to overcome, which is certainly considerable; but were there no such difficulty, and that the two Planets were very near, it would not be possible to pass from the Air of one to the Air of the other. Water is the Air of Fishes, they never pass into the Air of Birds, nor Birds into the Air of Fishes, not that the distance hinders them, but because each of them is confin'd to his own Air. We find that ours is mixt with Vapours more thick and gross than that of the Moon, therefore should an Inhabitant of the Moon venture upon the Confines of our World, he'd be drown'd in our Air at his first arrival, and we should see him tumble down dead before us.</P038>
source_segments: quand même elle ne s'y rencontreroit pas
dés qu'il entreroit dans notre Air
target_segments: If there were no more than flying in the matter
but were there no such difficulty
explanations: The French "S'il ne tenoit qu'à voler" (literally, "If it only depended on flying" or "If it were only a matter of flying") is a concise, somewhat idiomatic expression. The English translation "If there were no more than flying in the matter" expands on this by adding "in the matter," which explicitly defines the scope or context of the condition ("flying"). This addition makes explicit a general context that is only implicitly understood in the more condensed French phrase.

In the French phrase "il n'y a pas beaucoup d'apparence," (I confess there is not much likelihood/prospect), "d'apparence" refers to the likelihood of the previously discussed idea. The English translation "appearance of it" in the corresponding phrase "there is no great appearance of it," makes this referent explicit by adding "of it." While the referent (the possibility of flying between planets) is understood implicitly in the French, its explicit inclusion in English clarifies the object of 'appearance'.

The French "quand même elle ne s'y rencontreroit pas" (even if it [the difficulty] were not encountered there) uses the pronoun "elle" to refer anaphorically to "une difficulté" (a difficulty) mentioned earlier in the sentence. The English translation "but were there no such difficulty" replaces this pronominal reference by explicitly restating "difficulty" and adding the determiner "such." This makes the connection to the antecedent clearer and more direct than the French pronominal reference.

The French phrase "A ce compte" (literally "by this account" or "on this reckoning") serves as a discourse marker indicating a logical deduction or consequence based on the preceding statements. The English translation "therefore" explicitly lexicalizes this logical connection. While "A ce compte" implies causality or result, "therefore" states it more overtly, making the argumentative structure more patent.

The French phrase "se noyeroit dés qu'il entreroit dans notre Air" (would drown as soon as he entered our Air) emphasizes the immediacy of the consequence upon entry. The English translation renders this as "he'd be drown'd in our Air at his first arrival." The addition of "at his first arrival" clarifies and specifies the timing and nature of the event, suggesting not just any entry but the very initial one. This adds a layer of explicitness by specifying the instance of entry beyond the simple immediacy implied by the French "dés que".

chunks.source_manual: <P043>Oh, que j'aurois d'envie, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <UP></UP> qu'il arrivât quelque grand naufrage <UP></UP> qui répandît icy bon nombre de ces Gens- là, dont nous irions considérer à notre aise les figures extraordinaires! Mais répliquay-je, s'ils étoient assez habiles pour naviger sur la surface exterieure de notre Air, & que de là par la curiosité de nous voir, ils nous pêchassent comme des Poissons, cela vous plairoit-il? Pourquoy non, répondit-elle en riant? Pour moy, je me mettrois de mon propre mouvement dans leurs Filets, seulement pour avoir le plaisir de voir ceux qui m'auroient pêchée.</P043>
chunks.target_manual: <P039>Oh! cry'd the Marchioness, how I should rejoyce at a Shipwrack that would lay before us a good number of those people. We might then consider those extraordinary Figures at our leisure. But, said I, if they were expert enough to sail upon the exteriour surface of our Air, and should lay Nets and Hooks for us as we do for Fishes, would that please you? Why not, says she, laughing? for my part I would willingly put my self into their Nets, only to have the satisfaction of seeing them that caught me.</P039>
explanations: The French verb "pêchassent" (the third-person plural imperfect subjunctive of "pêcher," meaning "to fish") describes a general action of fishing. The English translation renders the core action as "lay Nets and Hooks," thereby making explicit the *means* or *method* of fishing (using nets and hooks), which was only implied by the general verb "pêcher" in the source text. This addition of specific implements by the translator also subtly alters the dialogue's progression, as in the original French, it is the Marquise who later first introduces the specific term "Filets" (Nets) in her response.

The French phrase "comme des Poissons" (literally, "like fish") establishes a simile, indicating that humans would be caught or treated in a manner analogous to how fish are. The English translation "as we do for Fishes" explicates this simile by specifying that the analogy refers to *human fishing practices* ("as we do"). This clarifies the basis of the comparison by making the implicit reference to human agency and methods (our way of fishing) explicit, rather than just the state of being treated 'like fish'.

chunks.source_manual: <P044>Songez, répliquai-je, que vous n'arriveriez que bien malade au haut de notre Air, il n'est pas respirable pour nous dans toute son étenduê, il s'en faut bien, il ne l'est déjà presque plus au haut de certaines <UP></UP> Montagnes, & je m'étonne bien que ceux qui ont la folie de croire que des Genies corporels habitent l'air le plus pur, ne disent aussi que ce qui fait que ces Genies ne nous rendent que des visites & tres-rares & très-courtes, c'est qu'il y en a peu d'entre eux qui sachent plonger, & que ceux-là même ne peuvent faire jusqu'au fond de cet air épais, où nous sommes, que des plongeons de très peu de durée <UP></UP>. Voilà donc bien des barrieres naturelles qui nous défendent la sortie de notre Monde, & l'entrée de celuy de la Lune. Tâchons du moins pour notre consolation à deviner ce que nous pourrons de ce Monde-là. Je croy, par exemple, qu'il faut qu'on y voye le Ciel, le Soleil, & les Astres d'une autre couleur que nous ne les voyons. Tous ces objets ne nous paroissent qu'au travers d'une espèce de Lunette naturelle qui nous les change. Cette Lunette, c'est notre Air, mêlé comme il est de vapeurs & d'exhalaisons, & qui ne s'étend pas bien haut. Quelques Modernes pretendent que de luy-même il est bleu aussi bien que l'eau de la Mer, & que cette couleur ne paroît dans l'un & dans l'autre qu'à une grande profondeur. Le Ciel, disent-ils, où sont attachées les Etoiles Fixes, n'a de luy-même aucune lumière, & par conséquent il devroit paroître noir; mais on le voit au travers de l'Air, qui est bleu, & il paraît bleu. Si cela est, les rayons du Soleil & des Etoiles ne peuvent passer au travers de l'Air sans se teindre un peu de sa couleur, & prendre autant de celle qui leur est naturelle. Mais quand même l'Air ne seroit pas coloré de lui-même, il est certain qu'au travers d'un gros brouillard, la lumiere d'un flambeau qu'on voit un peu de loin paroît toute rougeâtre, quoy que ce ne soit pas sa vraye couleur, & notre Air n'est non plus qu'un gros broüillard, qui nous doit alterer la vraye couleur & du Ciel & du Soleil & des Etoiles. Il n'appartiendroit qu'à la matière céleste de nous apporter la lumiere & les couleurs dans toute leur pureté <UP></UP>, & telles qu'elles sont. Ainsi, puis que l'Air de la Lune est d'une autre nature que notre Air, ou il est teint en luy-même d'une autre couleur, ou du moins c'est un autre broüillard qui cause une autre alteration aux couleurs des Corps celestes. Enfin, à l'égard des Gens de la Lune, cette Lunette au travers de laquelle on voit tout, est changée.</P044>
chunks.target_manual: <P040>But bethink your self, said I, that you may be ill when you arrive at the top of our Air, we cannot breath in all its extent, it must needs be so, for we cannot breath upon the tops of some Mountains; and I much wonder that those that have the folly to believe that certain corporeal Genii inhabit the purest Air, do not likewise say, that the reason why those Genii come so seldom to us, and make such short Visits, is because few among them are expert in Diving, and those that are, cannot dive to the bottom of our thick Air, to stay any long time. So that here you see three natural Barricades to prevent our going out of our World or entring that of the Moon. Yet let us try for our satisfaction, to guess what we can of that World. I believe, for example, that we might see the Heaven, Sun and Stars of another colour than we see them here. We behold all those Objects here through a kind of natural Perspective which shews them otherwise than they are, that Perspective is our Air, mixt as it is with Vapours and Exhalations, which extend not very high. Some Moderns pretend that in it self it is of a blue colour, as well as the Sea, and that that colour appears not either in the one or the other, but in a great depth. The Heaven of the fixed Stars, say they, has of it self no light, and consequently it would appear black; but we see it through the Air which is blue, and represents it blue to us. If that be so, the Rays of the Sun and Stars cannot pass through the Air. without receiving a little tincture of that colour, and losing some of their own; but were it so that the Air had no colour of its own, it is certain that the Light of a Flambeau seen through a thick mist appears red, though it be not its natural colour, and our Air is no more than a thick mist that changes the colour of the Heaven, Sun and Stars. So that the Air of the Moon being of another nature than our Air, or having in it self a tincture of another colour, or at least being another mist that causes that change of colour in the celestial bodies, the Perspective through which all is seen, in respect of the people of the Moon is changed.</P040>
source_segments: que des plongeons de très peu de durée.
& prendre autant de celle qui leur est naturelle.
target_segments: it must needs be so, for
which shews them otherwise than they are
and losing some of their own;
explanations: The French "il s'en faut bien," (far from it,) acts as an intensifier for the preceding negation and introduces an exemplification. The English "it must needs be so, for" transforms this into an explicit assertion of truth ("it must needs be so") and a logical connector ("for") that introduces the following clause as a justification or reason, thereby spelling out a relationship that was more implicitly conveyed in the French.

The French phrase "que des plongeons de très peu de durée." (nothing but dives of very short duration.) describes the nature of the genii's dives. The English translation "to stay any long time." (in the context of "cannot dive ... to stay any long time.") makes explicit the *consequence* of these short dives—their inability to remain for an extended period—which was only implied by the description of the dives themselves.

The French "bien des barrieres naturelles" (many natural barriers) uses an indefinite quantifier. The English translation "three natural Barricades" replaces this with a specific number ("three"), adding a level of concrete detail and specificity not present in the original text. This is an addition of clarifying (or specifying) information.

The French "qui nous les change." (which changes them for us.), referring to how the "Lunette naturelle" (natural lens/telescope) affects celestial objects, is general. The English "which shews them otherwise than they are" explicitly clarifies the *nature* of this change, specifying that the "Perspective" (lens) alters their appearance, making them seem different from their actual state.

The French "il paraît bleu." (it appears blue.) describes a state. The English "represents it blue to us." makes the role of the air more active by using "represents," explicitly stating that the air is the agent causing this appearance, and specifies the observer ("to us," which is more subtly implied in "paraît"). This spells out the causal mechanism and the observer's perspective more directly.

The French phrase "& prendre autant de celle qui leur est naturelle." (and take/lose as much of their natural color.) is condensed and potentially ambiguous. The English translation "and losing some of their own;" makes the meaning of "loss" explicit, thereby expanding and clarifying the original condensed expression about how the rays of the sun and stars are affected by passing through the air.

chunks.source_manual: <P045>Cela me fait préférer notre sejour à celuy de la Lune, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne saurois croire que l'assortiment des couleurs celestes y soit aussi beau qu'il l'est icy. Mettons, si vous voulez, un Ciel rouge, & des Etoiles vertes, l'effet n'est pas si agreable que des Etoiles couleur d'or sur du bleu. On diroit à vous entendre, <UP></UP>, repris-je, que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble; mais, croyez-moy, la Nature a bien de l'esprit; laissez-luy le soin d'inventer un assortiment de couleurs pour la Lune, & je vous garantis qu'il sera bien entendu. Elle n'aura pas manqué de varier le Spectacle de l'Univers à chaque point de veüe diferent <UP></UP>, & de le varier d'une manière toûjours agreable.</P045>
chunks.target_manual: <P041>That, says the Marchioness, makes me prefer our abode before that of the Moon; sor I cannot believe that the Appearance of the celestial colours is so pleasant there as here. Let us suppose a red Sky and green Stars, they will not agree so well together as Stars of a pure Gold-colour upon blue. Any that heard you, says I, would think you were dressing up a Suit of Clothes, or furnishing a Room; but believe me, Nature understands well enough what she does, leave it to her to invent a mixture of Colours for the Moon, and I'le undertake it shall be well approved. She fail'd not to work variety of Prospects in the Universe at every turn of the eye, and yet the variety is still pleasing.</P041>
source_segments: la Nature a bien de l'esprit
à chaque point de veüe diferent
target_segments: they will not agree so well together
dressing up a Suit of Clothes
Nature understands well enough what she does
at every turn of the eye
explanations: The French states the outcome ('the effect is not as pleasing'). The English explicates the *reason* for this by specifying that the colors themselves 'will not agree so well together,' making the implied cause (disharmony of colors) explicit.

The French 'des Etoiles couleur d'or' (gold-colored Stars) is general. The translator adds 'pure,' making explicit a specific quality (purity, intensity) of the gold color that was unstated in the original, thereby clarifying or enhancing the visual.

The French 'assortiriez un habit' (you would match/coordinate an outfit/garment) describes an act of selection. The English 'dressing up a Suit of Clothes' explicates this by detailing a more elaborate process of preparing and presenting clothes for appearance, and specifies 'habit' (garment/outfit) as 'a Suit of Clothes'.

The French 'un meuble' (a piece of furniture), understood with the elided verb 'assortiriez' (match/coordinate from the preceding clause: 'que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble'), refers to matching furniture. The English translation expands this into the much broader activity 'furnishing a Room,' explicating an entire process of interior decoration implied by matching a piece of furniture.

The French 'la Nature a bien de l'esprit' (Nature has much wit/intelligence) attributes a general quality. The English 'Nature understands well enough what she does' explicates this by interpreting 'esprit' in this context as practical competence and conscious understanding in her creative actions.

The French 'il sera bien entendu' suggests the assortment of colors will be well-conceived or inherently harmonious. The English 'it shall be well approved' makes explicit the idea of a positive external judgment or reception of this assortment, a consequence which was at most implied in the French.

The French 'à chaque point de veüe diferent' (at each different viewpoint) is an abstract expression. The English 'at every turn of the eye' makes this concrete by explicitly stating the physical action (turning the eye) that results in a change of viewpoint.

The French conjunction represented by '&' (et/and) simply connects two actions of Nature. The English 'and yet' (as in 'and yet the variety is still pleasing') introduces and makes explicit a concessive relationship: *despite* the variation Nature creates, the result is pleasing, a nuance not directly stated by the simple French conjunction.

chunks.source_manual: <P046>Je reconnois son adresse, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle s'est épargné la peine de changer les objets pour chaque point de veûe, elle n'a changé que les Lunettes, & elle a l'honneur de cette grande diversité, sans en avoir fait la dépense. Avec un air bleu, elle nous donne un Ciel bleu, & peut-être avec un Air rouge, elle donne un Ciel rouge aux Habitans de la Lune, c'est pourtant toûjours le même Ciel. Il me paroît qu'elle nous a mis dans l'imagination certaines Lunettes, au travers desquelles on voit tout, & qui changent fort les objets à l'égard de chaque homme. Alexandre voyoit la Terre comme une belle place bien propre à y établir un grand Empire. Celadon ne la voyoit que comme <RW>le sejour d'Astrée</RW>. Un Philosophe la voit comme une grosse Planète qui va par les Cieux, toute couverte de fous. Je ne croy pas que le Spectacle change plus de la Terre à la Lune, qu'il fait icy d'imagination à imagination.</P046>
chunks.target_manual: <P042>I know her Artifice, said the Marchioness, she spar'd her self the pains of making variety of Objects, and only chang'd the Perspectives; so that she has the Honour of that great Diversity without being at the Expence. With a blue Air she gives us a blue Sky, and possibly with a red Air she gives the Inhabitants of the Moon a red Sky, but still 'tis the same Sky. In my opinion she has likewise plac'd in our imagination certain Perspectives, through which we see all, and which change the Objects in respect of every particular man. Alexander saw the Earth a fair place fit for the Seat of a great Empire; Celadon sees it only as the abode of his Astrea, and a Philosopher sees it only as a great Planet moving in the Heavens and throng'd with Fools. I do not believe that the prospect is more different between the Earth and the Moon, than between Imagination and Imagination.</P042>
target_segments: the Seat of a great Empire
explanations: The French "Lunettes" (literally "glasses" or "spectacles"), from "elle n'a changé que les Lunettes", is translated as "Perspectives" in "only chang'd the Perspectives." In the 17th-century context of the work, "Perspectives" could refer to optical instruments like spy-glasses or telescopes that define or alter one's view. The translator's choice makes explicit the *function* of these metaphorical "lunettes" as instruments significantly shaping perception, rather than simple eyeglasses, clarifying an implication present in the original.

Similarly, the French "Lunettes" from "certaines Lunettes" is translated to "Perspectives" in "certain Perspectives." This choice again explicates that these metaphorical "lunettes" placed in the imagination are not merely spectacles but conceptual or optical tools that fundamentally alter how objects are perceived by each individual, adding a layer of specificity about their perception-altering nature that was implicit in the more general French term.

The French phrase "établir un grand Empire" (to establish a great empire), in the context of Earth being a place "bien propre à y établir un grand Empire" (very suitable for establishing a great empire there), implies a location for this empire. The translation "fit for the Seat of a great Empire" makes explicit the idea that the Earth is envisioned not just as a general location for an empire, but specifically as its *central base* or *capital*. The addition of "the Seat of" specifies this role which was only implied in the original's more general phrasing.

The French "le sejour" from "le sejour d'Astrée" (which can mean a temporary 'stay' or 'sojourn' as well as a 'dwelling') is translated as "the abode" in "the abode of his Astrea". The English word "abode" more specifically implies a place of residence or a home. This translation choice makes explicit the interpretation of Astrée's presence on Earth as a settled dwelling, clarifying the nature of the "sejour" in Celadon's view, as opposed to a more transient stay.

The French text refers to "Astrée" (Astraea) in the phrase "le sejour d'Astrée". The translation renders this as "his Astrea" in "the abode of his Astrea". The addition of the possessive pronoun "his" makes explicit Celadon's personal and amorous relationship with Astraea, a key aspect of the literary work (*L'Astrée*) being referenced. This relational information, while inferable by contemporary readers familiar with the romance, is directly spelled out by the translator.

The French "toute couverte de fous" (all covered with fools) is translated as "throng'd with Fools". While "toute couverte" implies a significant presence and large number, the phrase "throng'd with" explicitly emphasizes the *density* and *overwhelmingly crowded nature* of this presence. It makes the implicit idea of Earth being overrun or densely populated by fools more vivid and direct than the more general "covered with."

The French "Un Philosophe la voit comme..." (A philosopher sees it as...) describes the philosopher's perspective without an explicit term of restriction equivalent to the "ne...que" (only) used for Celadon's view. The translation "a Philosopher sees it only as..." introduces the word "only". This addition makes explicit a restrictive sense (i.e., the philosopher sees the Earth *exclusively* or *merely* in this way), thereby aligning the philosopher's perceived view more closely with Celadon's explicitly restricted view.

chunks.source_manual: <P047>Le changement de spectacle est plus surprenant dans nos imaginations, répliquay-je, car ce ne sont que les mêmes objets qu'on voit si diferemment; du moins dans la Lune on peut voir d'autres objets, ou ne pas voir quelques-uns de ceux qu'on voit icy. Peut-être ne connaissent-ils point en ce Pays-là l'Aurore, ny les Crepuscules, avant che le Soleil se leve, ou après qu'il est couché. L 'Air qui nous environne, & qui est élevé au-dessus de nous, reçoit des rayons qui ne pourroient pas tomber sur la Terre; & parce qu'il est fort grossier, il en arrête une partie, & nous les renvoye, quoy qu'ils ne nous fussent pas naturellement destinés. Ainsi l'Aurore & les Crépuscules sont une grace que la Nature nous fait; c'est une lumiere que regulièrement nous ne devrions point avoir, & qu'elle nous donne par dessus ce qui nous est dû. Mais dans la Lune, où apparemment l'Air est plus pur, il pourroit bien n'être pas si propre à renvoyer en en bas les rayons qu'il reçoit du Soleil avant qu'il se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. Vous n'avez donc cette lumiere de faveur <NCP></NCP>, qui en se fortifiant peu à peu, vous prepare agreablement à l'arrivée du Soleil, ou qui en s'affoiblissant comme de nuance en nuance, vous accoûtume à sa perte. Vous êtes dans des tenebres profondes <NCP></NCP>, & tout d'un coup il semble qu'on tire un rideau, voilà vos yeux frapez de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil; vous êtes dans une lumière vive & éclatante, & tout d'un coup vous voilà tombés dans des tenebres profondes. Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre. L'Arc-en-ciel est encore une chose qui manque aux Gens de la Lune, car si l'Aurore est un effet de la grossiereté de l'air & des vapeurs, l'Arc-en-ciel se forme dans les nuages d'ou tombent les pluyes, & nous devons les plus belles choses du monde à celles qui le sont le moins. Puis <UP></UP> qu'il n'y a autour de la Lune ny vapeurs assez grossières, ny nuages pluvieux, adieu l'Arc-en-ciel avec l'Aurore, & à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là? Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!</P047> <P048>Je n'aurois pas grand regret à ces comparaisons là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, & je trouve qu'on est assez bien recompense dans la Lune <UP></UP>, de n'avoir ny Aurore ny Arc-en- ciel, car on ne doit avoir par la même raison ny Foudres ny Tonnerres, puisque ce sont aussi des choses qui se forment dans les nüages. On a de beaux jours toûjours serains pendant lesquels on ne perd point le Soleil de venë <NCE></NCE>. On n'a point de nuits où toutes les Etoiles ne se montrent <UP></UP>; on ne connoît ny les orages, ny les tempêtes, ny tout ce qui paroît être un effet de la colere du Ciel, trouvez-vous qu'on soit tant à plaindre? Vous me faites voir la Lune comme un séjour enchanté, répondis-je; cependant je ne say s'il est si délicieux d'avoir toûjours sur la tête, un Soleil ardent dont aucun nüage ne modère la chaleur. Peut-être aussi est-ce à cause de cela que la Nature a creusé dans la Lune des especes de Puits, qui sont assez grands pour être apperçus par nos Lunettes; car ce ne sont point des Vallées qui soient entre des Montagnes, ce sont des creux que l'on voit au milieu de certains lieux plats. Que sait-on si les Habitans de la Lune, incommodez par l'ardeur perpetuelle du Soleil, ne se refugient point dans ces grands Puits? Ils n'habitent peut-être point ailleurs, c'est là qu'ils bâtissent leurs Villes. Nous voyons icy que la Rome soûterraine êtoit presque aussi grande que la Rome qui est sur Terre. Il ne faudroit qu'ôter celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la manière de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples. Vous vous moquez de cette vision, j'y consens de tout mon cur; cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plutôt que moy. Vous croyez que les Gens de la Lune doivent habiter sur la surface de leur Planete, parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nôtre: c'est tout le contraire, puisque nous habitons sur la surface de notre Planete, ils pourraient bien n'habiter pas sur la surface de la leur. D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien différentes. <UP></UP></P048>
chunks.target_manual: <P043>The change of the Prospect, says I, is more surprizing in our Imaginations, for they are but the same Objects which we see differently; but in the Moon other Objects are to be seen, or none of those that are seen here, possibly in that Country they know not Aurora nor the Twilight, before the Sun rises and after he sets; the Air that surrounds us and is rais'd above us, receives Rays which cannot fall upon the Earth, and being very thick, it stops some of them & reflects them upon us, tho they were not naturally design'd for us. So that Aurora and the Twilight is a particular favour of Nature, a Light which regularly we ought not to have, and which she gives us over and above our due. But it may not be so proper in •he???, where the Air is apparently more pure to beat down the Rays of the Sun before he rises or after he is set. You have not there that favourable Light, which growing upon you by degrees prepares you easily for the Arrival of the Sun, and which by the same degrees declining prepares you for his absence. You are in a profound Darkness, and all or a suddain, as though a Curtain were drawn, you find your eyes struck with the Light of the Sun; again you are in a bright and vigorous Light, and all on a suddain you drop into a profound Darkness, the day and night are not joined with a middle light that participates both of the one and the other. The Rainbow is likewise a thing wanting to the people of the Moon; for as the Aurora is an effect of the grossness of the Air and Vapours; so the Rainbow is form'd in Clouds from whence falls the Rain, so that we are oblig'd for the most beautiful thing in the World, to that which is the least so. Since then there are no gross Vapours about the Moon, nor rainy Clouds, farewell Rainbow, farewel Aurora, to what now must we resemble the fair ones of that Country? What a fource of comparisons is there lost! I am not much concern'd, said the Marchioness, for those comparisons, and I find recompence enough in the Moon for the want of the Rainbow and Aurora; for by the same reason there is neither Thunder nor Lightning, both which are form'd in the Clouds, the days are still fair and serene, and the Sun in the day time never out of sight, the Stars are visible all night, no Storm or Tempest is ever known, nor any thing that is an effect of an angry Heaven. What reason do you find then of Complaint? You represent the Moon to me, said I, as an inchanted abode, but in the mean time I know not whether it be so pleasant to have daily a scorching Sun over a mans head, and not a Cloud to moderate the Heat, it may be likewise 'tis therefore Nature has made certain kind of Pits in the Moon big enough to be discern'd by our Glasses; for they are not mountains? but hollow places which appear in the midst of certain plains. How do we know but the Inhabitants of the Moon shelter themselves there from the extremity of the Heat? possibly they live no where else but there, and 'tis there they build their Towns. We see here that the Subterranean Rome was almost as big as Rome above the Earth; there needs no more than to take away this, the rest will be a Town like those in the Moon; a whole Populace is together in one of those Cavities, and from one to another they communicate by subterraneous ways. You laugh now at this Vision, and I heartily agree you should, but in the mean time to tell you seriously, you may be deceived sooner than I. You think the people of the Moon ought to inhabit upon the surface of their Planet as we do upon ours. 'Tis quite contrary; though we live upon the surface of our Planet, they may not at all live upon the surface of theirs, all things ought to be very different here from what they are there.</P043>
source_segments: parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nôtre
target_segments: here from what they are there
explanations: The French "comme de nuance en nuance" (as from shade to shade) poetically describes a gradual weakening. The English phrase "by the same degrees" (which modifies "declining," the translation of "s'affoiblissant" - weakening) makes the gradualness explicit ("by degrees") and adds "the same." This addition explicitly spells out a symmetrical relationship with the earlier described gradual increase of light ("growing...by degrees"), a relationship that was implied but not explicitly stated in the French.

The French "un milieu" (a middle/medium), in the context of the transition between full daylight and complete darkness, refers to an intermediary state. The translator makes the implicit nature of this state explicit by specifying it as "a middle light," thereby adding clarifying information that this intermediary state specifically pertains to illumination.

The French "la tête" (the head) refers generally to the head of any inhabitant in that situation. The English "a mans head" makes this more concrete by specifying a generic human subject ("a man's" used here to represent any person), thereby explicitating the implied possessor of the head in a more specific, though generic, representative manner.

The French clause "parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nôtre" (because we inhabit the surface of ours) explicitly states the *reason* for the Marquise's belief as a separate causal explanation. The English translation changes this to "as we do upon ours," which functions as an adverbial modifying how the Moon people are thought to inhabit their planet. This restructuring makes the *analogical thinking* (i.e., that they live *in the same way as* Earth's inhabitants) an explicit component of the description of the belief itself, rather than a separately stated cause.

The French "D'icy là" (literally "from here to there") is a condensed expression implying a comparison of conditions or the state of things between Earth and the Moon. The English phrase "here from what they are there" expands this by explicitly naming the locations of comparison ("here" and "there") and specifying that the comparison pertains to "what they are" (i.e., the state of things or conditions), thus spelling out the nature and terms of the comparison more fully.

chunks.source_manual: <P049>Il n'importe, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne puis me resoudre à laisser vivre les Habitans de la Lune dans une obscurité perpetuelle. Vous y auriez encore plus de peine, répris-je, si vous saviez qu'un grand Philosophe de l'Antiquité a fait de la Lune le séjour des âmes qui ont merité icy d'être bien-heureuses. Toute leur felicité consiste en ce qu'elles y entendent l'Harmonie que les Corps Celestes font par leurs mouvements; mais comme il pretend que quand la Lune tombe dans l'ombre de la Terre, elles ne peuvent plus entendre cette Harmonie <UP></UP>; alors, dit-il, ces Ames crient comme des desesperées, & la Lune se hâte le plus qu'elle peut de les tirer d'un endroit si fâcheux. Nous devrions donc, répliqua-t-elle, voir arriver icy les Bienheureux de la Lune, car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi; & dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde. Serieusement, repris-je, ce ne seroit pas un plaisir mediocre de voir plusieurs Mondes differens. Ce Voyage me réjoüit quelquefois beaucoup à ne le faire qu'en imagination, & que seroit-ce, si on le faisoit en effet? Cela vaudroit bien mieux que d'aller d'icy au Japon, c'est- à-dire de ramper avec beaucoup de peine d'un point de la Terre sur un autre, pour ne voir que des hommes. Eh bien, dit-elle, faisons le Voyage des Planètes comme nous pourrons; qui nous en empêche? Allons nous placer dans tous ces differens points de veuê, & de là considérons l'Univers. N'avons- nous plus rien à voir dans la Lune? Je croy que non, répondis-je du moins je vous y ay fait voir tout ce qui êtoit de ma connoissance. Au sortir de la Lune en tirant vers le Soleil, on trouve Vénus. Sur Vénus je reprens le <NCE>Saint-Denis</NCE>. Vénus tourne sur elle-même, & autour du Soleil <UP>comme la Lune</UP>, on découvre avec les <NCP><IIM>Lunettes d'approche</IIM></NCP>, que Vénus aussi bien que la Lune est tantôt en Croissant, tantôt en Décours, tantôt pleine selon les diverses situations où elle est à l'égard de la Terre. La Lune, selon toutes les apparences, est habitée, pourquoy Vénus ne le sera-t-elle pas aussi? Mais, interrompit-elle, en disant toüjours Pourquoy non, vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planètes? N'en doutez pas, répliquay-je, ce Pourquoy a une vertu qui suffira pour peupler tout. Nous voyons que toutes les Planètes sont de la même Nature, toutes des Corps <IIM>opaques</IIM> qui ne reçoivent de la lumière que du Soleil, qui se la renvoyent les uns aux autres, & qui n'ont que les mêmes mouvements, jusque là tout est égal. Cependant, il faudroit concevoir que ces grands Corps auroient êté faits pour n'être point habitez, que ce seroit là leur condition naturelle, & qu'il y aurait une exception justement en faveur de la Terre toute seule. Qui voudra le croire, le croye; pour moi, je ne m'y puis pas resoudre? Je vous trouve, dit-elle, bien affermy dans vôtre opinion depuis quelques instans. <UP></UP> Je viens de voir le moment que la Lune seroit deserte, & que vous ne vous en souciîez pas beaucoup, & presentement si on osoit vous dire que toutes les Planetes ne sont pas aussi habitées que la Terre, je voy bien que vous vous mettriez en colere. Il est vray, répondis-je, que dans le moment où vous venez de me surprendre, si vous m'eussiez contredit sur les Habitans des Planetes, non seulement je vous les aurois soutenus, mais je crois que je vous aurois dit comment ils êtoient tous faits. Il y a des momens pour croire, & je ne les ay jamais si bien crûs que dans celuy là; presentement que je suis un peu plus de sens froid, je ne laisse pas de trouver qu'il seroit bien étrange que la Terre fût aussi habitée qu'elle l'est, & que les autres Planètes ne le fussent point du tout; car ne croyez pas que nous voyions tout ce qui habite la Terre; il y a autant d'espèces d'Animaux invisibles que de visibles. Nous voyons depuis l'Eléphant jusqu'au <UP></UP> Ciron; là finit notre veuë; mais au Ciron commence une multitude infinie d'Animaux, dont il est l'Eléphant, & que la simple veuë ne sauroit apercevoir. On a vu avec des <RW>Lunettes</RW> beaucoup de Liqueurs toutes remplis de petits Animaux que l'on n'aurait jamais soupçonnez d'y être, & il y a quelque apparence que le goût quelles font sentir, sont les piqueures que ces petits Animaux font à la langue & au palais. Mêlez de certaines choses dans quelques-unes de ces Liqueurs, ou exposez-les au Soleil, ou laissez-les se corrompre, voilà aussi-tôt de nouvelles especes de petits Animaux.</P049>
chunks.target_manual: <P044>'Tis no matter, said the Marchioness, I cannot resolve to let the Inhabitants of the Moon live in perpetual obscurity. But you would be yet more concern'd, said I, if you knew that an ancient and great Philosopher has made the Moon the abode of blessed Souls. All their Happiness consists in hearing there the Harmony which the celestial bodies make in their motions; but he pretends that when the Moon falls in the Shadow of the Earth, they cannot then hear that Harmony, and 'tis then those poor Souls cry out desperately, and the Moon makes what haste she can to deliver them out of that trouble. We may then, says she, expect to see the happy Souls of the Moon here; for 'tis certain they are sent likewise to us, as to their Paradice, and between those two Planets, the Moon and Earth, 'tis thought sufficient provision is made for the happiness of Souls by mutually transporting them into each others World. Seriously, said I, it would be no small pleasure to see many different Worlds; 'tis a pleasure to make the Voyage in imagination only, 'twould surely be much more so in effect. It would be much better than to go from hence to Iapan, that is to say, than to take the pains to run from one corner of the Earth to another, and all to see nothing else but men. Well, says she, let us take a Voyage about the Planets, as well as we can. What should hinder us? Let us place our selves in all those different points of sight, and from thence consider the World. Have we no more to see in the Moon? I think not, said I, at least I have shewn you all that is within my knowledge. Leaving the Moon and bending our Course toward the Sun, we meet Venus, and in Venus I return again to Saint Denis. Venus turns about her self and about the Sun, as the Moon doth; and it is found by the Telescope that Venus, as well as the Moon, has her Increases and Decreases, and is full, according to her diverse scituation in respect of the Earth.</P044> <P045>The Moon according to all appearance is inhabited, why not Venus as well? But, says she, in saying still, Why not, you seem to design Inhabitants for all the Planets. Doubt it not, said I, that Why has a vertue in it sufficient to people all. We see that the Planets are all of the same nature, all opaque bodies that receive no Light but the Suns, which they reflect from one to another, & have all the same motions; thus far all are equal. In the mean time we must conceive that those great bodies are made to be uninhabited, that that's their natural Condition, and that the Earth only was exempted from it. He that will believe so, let him believe; for my part I cannot concur with him. I find, says she, that you are very very much confirm'd in your opinion within this little while; it is not long since the Moon was made a Desert, and you were not much concern'd at it, and now should any one venture to tell you that all the Planets are not inhabited as the Earth is, I find you would be angry. 'Tis true, said I, at that moment when you surpriz'd me, had you contradicted me about the Inhabitants of the Planets, I should not only have maintain'd them against you, but I believe I should have told you how they are all made. There are moments for believing, and I never believ'd it so much as at that moment. But now in a cooler Judgment, I think it would be very strange that the Earth should be so well inhabited as it is, and the other Planets not at all; for I would not have you think that we see all that inhabits the Earth, there are as many species of Animals invisible as visible. We see down from the Elephant to <UP>the Mite and</UP> the Cicon, there our sight terminates; but from <UP>the Mite and</UP> the Cicon begins an infinite multitude of Animals to which the Mite is an Elephant, and which are not discernable to our plain sight. Glasses have discover'd to us many Liquors full of little Animals, which we should never have suspected to have been there; and 'tis not improbable that the Tast and Relish of those Liquors proceeds from the biting or sting of those Animals upon the tongue and palate. Do but mix some things with some of those Liquors, or expose them to the Sun, or let them corrupt, and you shall presently see a new species of little Animals.</P045>
source_segments: car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi
target_segments: for 'tis certain they are sent likewise to us, as to their Paradice
explanations: The translator adds 'as to their Paradice,' making explicit the implied nature of Earth as a place of happiness or a 'paradise' for the 'Bienheureux' (blessed/happy) souls sent from the Moon. The source implies a positive destination suitable for blessed souls ('on nous les envoye aussi' - they are also sent to us), and the translation specifies this with the highly connotative and explicit term 'Paradice,' potentially to resonate more strongly with the target audience's cultural or religious framework.

The French 'Lunettes d'approche' is a general term of the period for 'spyglasses' or 'magnifying optics for distance.' The translation 'Telescope' explicitly names the specific scientific instrument used for astronomical observations (implied by the context of discovering the phases of Venus). This clarification makes the means of discovery more precise for an audience engaging with a work popularizing new scientific understanding.

The French 'le goût' (the taste) is translated and expanded to 'the Tast and Relish.' The addition of 'and Relish' makes explicit a potentially more complex, distinct, or piquant quality of the taste, which was only implied by the general term 'goût.' This enhances the description of the sensory experience attributed to microscopic life, aligning with the popular science aim of making concepts vivid.

The French 'les piqueures' can refer to pricks, stings, or bites. The translation 'the biting or sting' explicitly enumerates two distinct types of actions these microscopic animals might perform to cause the sensation on the tongue and palate. This spells out the specific mechanisms, making the nature of the 'piqueures' more concrete and understandable than the more general French term.

chunks.source_manual: <P050>Beaucoup de Corps qui paroissent solides <UP></UP>, ne sont que des amas de ces Animaux imperceptibles, qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut. Une feüille d'Arbre est un petit Monde habité par des Vermisseaux invisibles, à qui elle paroît d'une étenduë immense, qui y connaissent des Montagnes & des Abîmes, & qui d'un côté de la feüille à l'autre, n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent, que nous avec nos Antipodes. A plus forte raison, ce me semble, une <RW>grosse</RW> Planete sera-t-elle un Monde habité. On a trouvé jusque dans des especes de pierres tres dures de petits Vers sans nombre, qui y étoient logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles, & qui ne se nourrissoient que de la substance de ces pierres qu'ils rongeaient. Figurez-vous combien il y avoit de ces petits Vers, & pendant combien d'années ils subsistoient de la grosseur d'un grain de sable; & sur cet exemple, quand la Lune ne seroit qu'un amas de rochers, je la ferois plutôt ronger par ses Habitans que de n'y en pas mettre. Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé <UP></UP>: mettez toutes ces especes d'Animaux nouvellement découvertes, & même toutes celles que l'on conçoit aisément qui sont encore à découvrir, avec celles que l'on a toûjours veuës, vous trouverez assurément que la Terre est bien peuplée, & que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vît seulement la moitié. Croirez-vous qu'aprés qu'elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'exces, elle a êté pour toutes les autres Planètes d'une stérilité à n'y rien produire de vivant?</P050>
chunks.target_manual: <P046>Many bodies that seem solid, are only a heap of those indiscernable Animals, which find as much liberty for motion there, as they need. The Leaf of a Tree is a little World, inhabited by invisible Worms, to whom it seems a place of immense extent, there they find Mountains and Abysses, and the Worms that inhabit on one side of the Leaf, have no more communication with those on the other side, than we have with the Antipodes. With much more reason, in my opinion, a great Planet may be a World inhabited. There has been found even in some kind of exceeding hard Stones innumerable little Worms lodg'd in all parts in insensible vacuities, and were only nourish'd with the substance of the stone; imagine with your self how many little Worms there might be, and how many years they subsisted upon a bit no bigger than a grain of Sand; and according to this example, were the Moon only an heap of Rocks, rather than there should be no Inhabitants, I would make them gnaw upon those Rocks. In fine, all things have Life, all are animated; take you all those species of Animals newly discover'd, and those that we may easily judge are yet to be discover'd, together with those that we daily see, and you will certainly find that the Earth is well peopl'd, and that Nature has been so liberal in Animals, that she never took care that half of them should be seen: do you believe then, that having been so fruitful in her Productions here even to excess, she has been so barren in the other Planets, as to produce nothing living?</P046>
source_segments: de la grosseur d'un grain de sable
target_segments: upon a bit no bigger than a grain of Sand
explanations: The French phrase "d'une étenduë immense" (of an immense extent/expanse) describes how the leaf appears to the worms. The English translation "a place of immense extent" adds the noun "a place," thereby explicitly designating the leaf's surface as a specific location for these creatures. This was implied by "étenduë" (expanse/area) but is made more concrete and directly referential by the addition of "a place."

The French "de la grosseur d'un grain de sable" (literally, of the bigness/size of a grain of sand) refers to the minute quantity of substance on which the worms subsisted. The English translation "upon a bit no bigger than a grain of Sand" makes this more explicit by adding "a bit," which clarifies that "grosseur" (size/bigness) here refers to a small, discrete piece or quantity of the stone. This concretizes an abstract notion of size into a tangible amount of material.

The French "sa fecondité" (her fecundity) is part of the expression "elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'exces" (she has pushed her fecundity here to excess). The English translation renders this concept as "fruitful in her Productions" within the larger clause "having been so fruitful in her Productions here even to excess". The addition of "in her Productions" explicitly clarifies that Nature's inherent quality of "fecondité" is observed or manifested through its actual creations or "Productions," a detail that was implied but not directly stated in the original phrase.

chunks.source_manual: <P051>Ma raison est assez bien convaincuë, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, mais mon imagination est accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans de toutes ces Planètes, & embarrassée de la diversité qu'il faut établir entre eux; car je voy bien que la Nature, selon qu'elle est ennemie des repetitions, les aura tous faits différens, mais comment se representer cela? Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter, répondis-je, elle n'êst pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes. Tous les visages sont en general sur un même modele; mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent être faits sur deux modeles particuliers, & il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille. Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature pour varier en tant de manieres une chose aussi simple qu'un visage? Nous ne sommes dans l'Univers que comme une petite Famille, dont tous les visages se ressemblent; dans une autre Planète, c'est une autre Famille dont les visages ont un autre air. <UP></UP>.</P051>
chunks.target_manual: <P047>I am convinc'd, said the Marchioness, in my reason; but my imagination is overwhelm'd with that infinite multitude of Inhabitants in all the Planets, and confounded with the diversity that must needs be among them; for I well see that Nature, as she is an enemy of repetitions, has made them all different, but how shall we represent it? The Imagination, said I, cannot pretend to represent it, she can go no farther than the Eyes lead her: one certain general view may give a prospect of that diversity that Nature has wrought in all those Worlds. All Faces in general are wrought according to one and the same model, but those of two great Nations, of the Europeans, for example, and Africans seem to be fram'd to two particular models, and we may yet find a particular model in the Faces of every Family. What secret should Nature have in framing such variety in one only thing so simple as a Face? We are in the Universe but as one little Family, where all the Faces resemble; another Planet is another Family, where the Faces have another Air.</P047>
source_segments: aller plus loin que les yeux
On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité
paroissent être faits sur deux modeles particuliers
target_segments: that must needs be among them
go no farther than the Eyes lead her
one certain general view may give a prospect of that diversity
are wrought according to one and the same model
seem to be fram'd to two particular models
explanations: The French "qu'il faut établir entre eux" suggests a diversity that needs to be conceptually established or posited by an observer. The English "that must needs be among them" explicitates this diversity as an inherent and objective reality ("must needs be"), shifting the focus from an epistemological necessity (what one must conceive) to an ontological one (what necessarily exists).

The French phrase "aller plus loin que les yeux" (to go further than the eyes), within the context of imagination's limits ("elle n'êst pas propre à..."), describes a boundary set by perception. The English "go no farther than the Eyes lead her" explicitates an active role for the eyes ("lead her") in guiding and thereby restricting the imagination, a specific dynamic not explicitly stated in the more general French phrasing.

The French "On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité" (One can only perceive, by means of a certain universal view, the diversity) casts "On" (One) as the perceiver and the "veuë universelle" as the instrument. The English "one certain general view may give a prospect of that diversity" re-writes this by making the "view" itself the active subject that *provides* or *offers* ("may give a prospect of") the understanding of diversity, thus explicitating its agency in revealing this diversity.

The French "sont sur un même modele" (are on the same model) describes a state of conformity. The English "are wrought according to one and the same model" explicitates the process of active creation or fashioning ("wrought") which is only implied by "modele" (model/pattern) in the source, emphasizing that faces are deliberately made rather than just existing on a model.

The French "paroissent être faits sur deux modeles particuliers" (appear to be made on two particular models) uses the general verb "faits" (made). The English "seem to be fram'd to two particular models" employs the more specific verb "fram'd," which explicitates the idea of a structured design and deliberate construction, making the process of formation more vivid and concrete than the general "faits."

The French "pour varier" (to vary / in order to vary), in the context of Nature's actions, indicates the purpose or act of creating variation. The English "in framing such variety" explicitates the *method* or specific *act* ("in framing") by which Nature achieves this variation. This specifies the creative process implied in "varier," rephrasing the verb into a resultant noun ("variety") achieved through a distinct constructive action ("framing").

chunks.source_manual: <P052>Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne, & qui verroit un Habitant de la Lune, & un Habitant de la Terre, remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisins qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne. Icy, <NCP>par exemple</NCP>, on a l'usage de la voix, ailleurs on ne parle que par signes; plus loin on ne parle point du tout. Icy, le raisonnement se forme entierement par l'experience; ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose, plus loin les Vieillards n'en savent pas plus que les Enfants. Icy, on se tourmente de l'avenir plus que du passé; plus loin on se tourmente ny de l'un ny de l'autre, & ceux-là ne sont peut-être pas les plus malheureux. On dit qu'il pourroit bien nous manquer un sixiéme Sens naturel, qui nous aprendroit beaucoup de choses que nous ignorons. Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde, où il manque quelqu'un des cinq que nous possedons. Peut-être même y a-t-il effectivement un grand nombre de Sens naturels; mais dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planètes, il ne nous en est échu que cinq, dont nous nous contentons faute d'en connoître d'autres. Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes que l'Esprit humain n'a jamais pû passer; il y a un point où elles nous manquent tout à coup, le reste est pour d'autres Mondes, où quelque chose de ce que nous savons est inconnu. <RW>Cette Planète-cy</RW> joüit des douceurs de l'Amour, mais elle est toûjours desolée en plusieurs de ses parties par les fureurs de la Guerre. Dans une autre Planète on joüit d'une Paix éternelle, mais au milieu de cette Paix on ne connoît point l'Amour, & on s'ennuye. Enfin ce que la Nature pratique en petit entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens, elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes, & elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en même temps que les compensations.</P052>
chunks.target_manual: <P048>'Tis most certain that the differences increase in proportion to the distances, and whoever should see an Inhabitant of the Moon and an Inhabitant of the Earth, would easily observe that they were of two Worlds nearer Neighbours than an Inhabitant of the Earth and an Inhabitant of Saturn; here for example we use the Voice, in another place they speak but by Signs, and farther off they speak not at all: Here Reason is wholly form'd by Experience, there Experience contributes little, and farther off old men know no more than children: Here we perplex our selves more for the future than what is past, farther off they concern themselves neither for the one nor the other, and those perhaps are not the most unhappy. It has been thought that we want a sixth natural Sense, by which we might know many things more than we do; that sixth Sense is doubtless in some other World, where possibly they want some one of our five: Nay, perhaps there are really a great number of natural Senses; but in the Distribution made with the Inhabitants of other Planets, only five fell to our share, wherewith we content our selves, because we know no other. Our Knowledge has certain bounds and limits which the Mind of Man cannot exceed, there is a certain point where it wholly fails us, and the rest is for some other World, where likewise something that we know is unknown: This Planet enjoys the Sweets of Love, but in many parts is laid desolate by the fury of War: In another Planet they enjoy perpetual Peace, but know nothing of Love, and are uneasie. In fine, what Nature has done in little among men in her distribution of Happiness or other Talents, she has doubtless done in great among the several Worlds, and did not at all forget that wonderful secret of hers in working a variety in all things, and yet at the same time making them equal by Compensations.</P048>
source_segments: égaler en même temps que les compensations
explanations: The French 'Apparemment,' which prefaces the clause 'les differences augmentent...', indicates that the statement is based on appearance or likelihood, implying a degree of reservation. The translation replaces this with ''Tis most certain that,' which explicitly asserts a high degree of certainty for the following clause. This explicitation of a strong assertive stance, not directly conveyed by the more nuanced 'Apparemment,' alters the author's original cautious or observational rhetorical style.

The French 'apparemment' in 'est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde' suggests the location of the sixth sense is a plausible inference or based on appearance, implying a speculative stance. The translation 'doubtless' replaces this nuance. By using 'doubtless,' the translator explicitly asserts the philosopher's conviction with a high degree of certainty not explicitly present in the more reserved 'apparemment,' thereby re-writing the speaker's epistemic stance.

The French 'égaler en même temps que les compensations' (to make equal at the same time as/with the compensations) suggests that equalization occurs concurrently with or as part of the mechanism of compensations. The translation 'making them equal by Compensations' explicitly spells out that compensations are the direct means or instrument through which equalization is achieved, clarifying an instrumental relationship that was more implicitly suggested by the source's phrasing.

The source text 'du bonheur où des talens' (literally 'of happiness where of talents') likely contains a typographical error, with 'où' (where) used instead of 'ou' (or), which the translator appears to have interpreted as 'ou des talens' (or talents). The translation 'of Happiness or other Talents' then adds the word 'other.' This addition explicitly frames 'Talents' as being additional to and distinct from 'Happiness' (or as a separate category of similar 'gifts'), thereby spelling out a specific relationship between the two distributed items that is not as explicit in the (presumed corrected) source 'du bonheur ou des talens'.

chunks.source_manual: <P053>Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous mavez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose même des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, répliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.</P053>
chunks.target_manual: <P049>Well, Madam, said I, laying aside my serious tone, are you now satisfied? Have I given you Chimera's enough? Truly, says she, I have now less trouble methinks to find out the difference of all those Worlds, my Imagination is now busie about the Plain you have given me. I represent to my self, as well as I can, extraordinary Characters and Customs for the Inhabitants of the Planets, and I frame strange and extravagant figures for them. I cannot well describe them to you, but I see something. As for those figures, says I, I advise you to remit them to the Dreams you will have this night, we shall see to morrow whether they assisted you well in it, and inform'd you of the Shape of the Inhabitants of any Planet.</P049>
target_segments: whether they assisted you well in it
explanations: The French "tout-à-fait bizarres" (completely/utterly bizarre) is rendered as "strange and extravagant". The translator expands the single, intensified adjective "bizarres" by using two distinct adjectives, "strange" and "extravagant". This makes explicit different facets of the unusual nature of the figures, where "extravagant" (exceeding reasonable limits, fantastic) spells out a specific dimension that, while potentially implied by the highly emphasized "bizarre", is not directly stated in the source.

The French "s'ils vous auront bien servie" (literally, "if they will have served you well") implies a context for this usefulness. The English translation "whether they assisted you well in it" makes this context explicit by adding the prepositional phrase "in it". This phrase refers back to the preceding discussion about the task of imagining the inhabitants of planets, thereby spelling out a connection that was only implied in the source text.

The French "comment sont faits les Habitants" asks broadly "how the Inhabitants are made/constituted/formed." The English translation specifies this inquiry as concerning "the Shape of the Inhabitants." This explicitly narrows the general question of the source text to the particular aspect of physical form, making one potential implication of "comment sont faits" explicit and central, thus altering the potentially broader scope of the original inquiry.

chunks.source_manual: <P054>QUATRIEME SOIR. Particularités des mondes de Vénus, de Mercure, de Mars, de Jupiter & de Saturne.</P054>
chunks.target_manual: <P050>THE Fourth Evening.</P050>

chunks.source_manual: <P055><SC>Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit iciy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.</SC> Nous en êtions à Vénus. On est bien sûr, dis-je à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que Venus tourne sur elle-même, <SC>mais on ne sait pas bien en quel temps</SC>, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroît une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroît d'icy, & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois petite que la Terre, elle paroît dedans Venus à peu prés de la même grandeur dont Venus nous paroît d'icy.</P055>
chunks.target_manual: <P051><UP>Our</UP> Dreams were not successful, they only represented something resembling what we had seen, and I had opportunity of reproching the Marchioness, as those people who never draw any thing but what is extravagant and grotesque reproch us at the sight of our Pictures. Very well, say they, those are men to the life, there's nothing there of fancy, We were fain then to be still ignorant of the Figures of the Inhabitants of the Planets, and content our selves with guessing at them as well as we could, continuing the Voyage we had began about the World: we were in Venus. 'Tis certain, said I to the Marchioness, that Venus turns about her self, but 'tis not well known in what time, nor consequently how long her days are; as for her years, they are but eight months, for in so much time she turns about the Sun. She is forty time less than the Earth, therefore the Earth in Venus seems a Planet forty times bigger than Venus appears to us from hence: and as the Moon is likewise forty times less than the Earth, she seems in Venus very near about the same bigness that Venus appears to us from hence.</P051>
source_segments: cela est tout fait comme des hommes
target_segments: those are men to the life
explanations: The French "ce que l'on voit iciy" (what one sees here) refers generally to familiar terrestrial reality. The translation "what we had seen" explicitates this by specifying that the familiar elements in the dreams are drawn from the characters' ("we") past ("had seen") specific experiences, rather than just general current reality ("one sees here").

The French "cela est tout fait comme des hommes" (that is all made like men), referring to the content of pictures ("Tableaux"), implies a realistic depiction. The translation "those are men to the life" explicitates this by clearly identifying "cela" as representations of "men" and specifying the nature of the resemblance ("comme des hommes") as "to the life" (lifelike), making the implied realistic portrayal explicit.

chunks.source_manual: <P056>Vous m'affligez, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroît trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroît de la même grandeur dont Vénus nous paroît d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y être Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger <NCE></NCE>. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. <UP></UP> C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour notre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Vénus; ces Gens là doivent nien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Vénus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. <UP></UP> Le climat est très favorable aux Amours. Vénus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.</P056>
chunks.target_manual: <P052>You vex me, said the Marchioness, I see well that the Earth is not for Venus, the Star of Shepherds and Mother of Love, as Venus is to the Earth; for the Earth in Venus appears too big, but the Moon that appears there of the same bigness that Venus doth to us from hence, is of a just proportion to be the Mother of Love and Star of Shepherds; those names are only fit for a little Planet that is brisk, clear, sparkling, and of a gallant Air. 'Tis certainly a destiny very pleasing to our Moon, to influence the Loves of the Inhabitants of Venus; those people must needs understand Gallantry well. Oh! no question on't, said I, the little people of Venus are made up of none but Celadons, and Sylvanders, and their most ordinary Conversation is beyond the most polite of Clelia, the Climate is extremely favourable for Love; Venus is nearer the Sun than we, and she receives from him a Light more lively and hot.</P052>
explanations: The French "une Planete" (a Planet) refers to a celestial body suitable for romantic names, contrasted with the Earth which appears "trop grande" (too big) from Venus in the preceding dialogue. The adjective "jolie" (pretty) also applied to this planet implies daintiness. The translator makes the implied characteristic of smallness explicit by adding the adjective "little", thereby clarifying information that was only suggested by the context and the adjective "jolie" in the source text.

The French "les plus belles de Clesie" refers to "the most beautiful conversations of/from Clélie," a 17th-century novel famed for its refined, gallant, and mannered dialogues characteristic of salon culture. The general term "belles" (beautiful) in this context implicitly encompasses qualities such as politeness, wit, and sophisticated social grace. The translator makes the specific aspect of politeness explicit by rendering "belles" as "polite," thus clarifying a key, culturally understood characteristic of these idealized conversations.

The French "de presider aux Amours" (to preside over the Loves) suggests a metaphorical guiding or leading role for the Moon concerning romantic matters on Venus. This act of "presiding" in such a context implies exerting some form of effect or sway. The translation "to influence the Loves" makes this implied effect or mechanism explicit, clarifying that the Moon's "presidency" is understood as an active power to affect or shape, a nuance less directly stated by the more general verb "presider."

chunks.source_manual: <P057>Je vois presentement, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, comment sont faits les Habitans de Vénus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Fêtes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, répliquai-je, que vous ne connaissez guère bien les Habitans de Vénus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient été auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.</P057>
chunks.target_manual: <P053>I now see, said the Marchioness, interrupting me, how the Inhabitants of Venus are made, they are like the Moors of Granada, a little black people, Sun-burnt, full of spirit and fire, always amorous, given to Poetry and Musick, and every day Feasting, Dancing and Tilting. Let me tell you, Madam, said I, you know but little of the Inhabitants of Venus; our Moors of Granada for the coldness and stupidity of their Temper would be to them but as people of Lapland or Groenland.</P053>
source_segments: faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique
pour la froideur & pour la stupidité
target_segments: for the coldness and stupidity of their Temper
explanations: The French verb "interrompit" (interrupted), with "la Marquise" as its subject in the full sentence, implies that the speaker (the philosopher narrating) was the one interrupted. The English translation "interrupting me" makes this implied object ("me") explicit, directly stating who was interrupted by the Marchioness. This spells out a relationship (interrupter-interrupted) that was contextually implicit.

The French present participles "faisant des Vers" (making verses/writing poetry) and "aimant la Musique" (loving music) describe activities and states of preference. The English translation "given to Poetry and Musick" rephrases these as a defined characteristic or habitual inclination ("given to"), thus making explicit the idea that these are deep-seated traits of the inhabitants rather than merely activities they engage in or feelings they possess.

The French phrase "pour la froideur & pour la stupidité" (literally "for the coldness and for the stupidity") indicates these qualities as the reason for a comparison. The English translation "for the coldness and stupidity of their Temper" adds the specific qualifier "of their Temper," thereby explicitly attributing these abstract qualities to the inherent disposition or character of the people being described. This clarifies that the coldness and stupidity are considered intrinsic traits.

chunks.source_manual: <P058>Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. <UP></UP> Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de mémoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvements subits, & <IIM>qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.</IIM> <NCE></NCE> Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoie une lumière si forte, que s'ils étoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de très <IIM>foibles</IIM> Crepuscules, & peut-être n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur lui, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un <RW>grand poële ardent</RW>, peu éloigné de leurs tête, & qui va d'une rapidité profigeuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent après la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Vénus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroître assez grandes. Pour les autres Planètes, comme elles sont au-delà de la <IIM>Terre vers le Firmament</IIM>, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumière, peut-être n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien faché de voir cette <RW>grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient</RW>, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. <SC>—</SC>.</P058>
chunks.target_manual: <P054>But what are the Inhabitants of Mercury? they are yet nearer the Sun, and therefore certainly must needs be fools with too much vivacity. I believe they have no memory no more than the greatest part of Negro's and that they never consider on any thing, nor act but by chance, and suddain motions; and in fine, that <IIM>Mercury is the Bedlam</IIM> of the Universe. They see the Sun much bigger than we do, because they are much nearer, and he gives them so strong a light, that were they here, they would esteem our fairest days but as weak twilight, and perhaps would not be able to distinguish Objects by it, and they are us'd to so excessive a Heat, that they would freez in the midst of Africa; their year is but three months, the length of their day is yet unknown to us; for Mercury is so little and so near the Sun, in whose Rays he is almost continually lost, that he escapes all observation of Astronomers, and they cannot yet lay hold on him so much as to observe what motion he makes about his Center: but his smalness makes them believe that he performs that Course in a little time, and that therefore the days in Mercury are short, and that the Inhabitants see the Sun like <NCE>a great burning Stove or Kettle</NCE> not far above their heads, and moving with a prodigious rapidity. It is well for them, for 'tis certain they are very desirous of the night, during which time they are inlightened by Venus and the Earth, which ought to appear very big to them. As for the other Planets, they being beyond the Earth toward the Firmament, seem less to them than they do to us, and they receive but little or perhaps no Light at all from thence. The fixed Stars likewise seem less to them, and many are not seen at all, which in my opinion is a loss. I am not well pleas'd to see that great Arch adorn'd with lesser Stars, and not to see the rest but in a less proportion and a duller colour.</P054>
source_segments: que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.
apparemment ils soûpirent après la nuit.
qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes,
target_segments: that Mercury is the Bedlam of the Universe.
like a great burning Stove or Kettle,
for 'tis certain they are very desirous of the night,
that he escapes all observation of Astronomers,
explanations: The French "Petites Maisons" is an idiomatic expression for asylums. The translation to "Bedlam", the name of a famous historical asylum in London, makes the implied meaning of 'a place of madness' explicit and culturally specific for an English readership, thereby adding clarifying information.

The French "un grand poële ardent" translates to 'a large burning stove/pan'. The English translation "a great burning Stove or Kettle" expands on this by adding "or Kettle". This explicitation clarifies the type of intensely hot, metallic object Fontenelle is describing by offering an additional, familiar example, making the implied category of such objects more concrete for the reader.

The French "apparemment" means 'apparently' or 'seemingly', suggesting a probable inference. The English translation "'tis certain" elevates this to a definitive statement. This explicitation makes the narrator's implied strong conviction or the perceived obviousness of the conclusion explicit as an assertion of certainty.
