The translation 'what would otherwise have remain'd useless' makes this implicit condition explicit by adding the adverb 'otherwise,' thereby spelling out the counterfactual scenario.

The French 'il rentre en luy-même' (it withdraws/re-enters into itself) is a general description of an action. The translation 'contracts it self' makes explicit a specific physical mechanism (contraction) for this action, which was only implied in the more general source text phrasing.

chunks.source_manual: <P098>J'aime fort toutes ces Idées-là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. J'aime ces Ballons qui s'enflent & se desenflent à chaque moment, & ces Mondes qui se combattent toûjours, & sur tout j'aime à voir comment ce combat fait entre eux un commerce de lumière, qui asseurément est le seul qu'ils puissent avoir.</P098>
chunks.target_manual: <P095>I have a great kindness, said the Marchioness, for these Idea's, I love these Bladders that swell and fall again every moment, and these Worlds that combat one another, and above all, I am pleas'd to see that the Combate produces an intercourse of Light between them, which is certainly the only Commerce they can have.</P095>
explanations: The concise French "J'aime fort" (I like very much/I love) is rendered with the more elaborate phrase "I have a great kindness". This expansion specifies a particular nuance of affection ('kindness') which is a plausible interpretation of "j'aime fort" but not its sole meaning, thus making a potential aspect of the emotion more explicit and using a more ornate expression.

The French "Ballons," meaning generally inflated objects or balls, is translated as "Bladders." "Bladder" specifies a particular type of inflatable object (a membranous sac), making Fontenelle's metaphorical cosmic entities more concrete and tangible. This adds clarifying information about the imagined nature of these "Ballons" that was only broadly implied by the original, more general term.

In the phrase "ce combat fait entre eux un commerce de lumière," the general French verb "fait" (from "faire," meaning to do/make) is translated as "produces" in "the Combate produces an intercourse of Light." The verb "produces" is more specific, explicitly stating that the combat generates or brings about the intercourse of light, thus clarifying the causal nature of the action that was more broadly implied by the versatile verb "fait."

The French "se desenflent" (deflate or shrink), describing the action of the "Ballons," is translated as "fall again." Instead of a direct translation of the process of deflation, "fall again" describes a potential physical consequence or a more vivid visual image associated with deflation (e.g., an object losing buoyancy or internal structure and thereby collapsing or falling). This makes the description of the "Bladders'" behavior more explicit about a resulting action or visual effect.

chunks.source_manual: <P099>Non, non, repris-je, ce n'est pas le seul. Les Mondes voisins nous envoyent quelquefois visiter, & même assez magnifiquement. Il nous en vient des Cometes, qui sont toûjours ornées, ou d'une chevelure éclatante, ou d'une barbe venerable, ou d'une queüe majestueuse.</P099>
chunks.target_manual: <P096>No, no, said I, that's not the only Correspondence; the neighbouring Worlds send sometimes to visit us, and that with Magnificence enough: there come Comets to us from thence, which are ever adorn'd, either with a bright shining Perriwig, or a venerable Beard, or a Majestick Tail.</P096>
explanations: The French 'le seul' (the only one), referring to the previously discussed way other worlds 'visit,' is translated as 'the only Correspondence.' The translator makes the implicit nature of this 'visit' or interaction explicit by specifying it as a 'Correspondence,' thereby defining the relationship or type of communication more narrowly than the general term in the source text, which only implied such a connection through the context of 'visiter' (to visit).

The French phrase 'd'une chevelure éclatante' (with/of a shining head of hair), describing an adornment of comets, is translated as 'with a bright shining Perriwig.' 'Chevelure' (head of hair) can be natural, though Fontenelle's use of 'ornées de' (adorned with) implies an ornamental quality. The translation 'Perriwig' (a wig) makes the artificial, fashionable (17th-century), and distinctly ornamental nature of this 'hair' explicit, clarifying it as a specific type of adornment that was only implied in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P100>Ah! quels Deputez dit-elle en riant! On se passeroit bien de leur visite, elle ne sert qu'à faire peur. Ils ne font peur qu'aux <UP></UP> enfants, repliquay-je, à cause de leur équipage extraordinaire, mais <RW>les enfants sont en grand nombre</RW>. Les Cometes ne sont que des Planetes qui appartiennent à un Tourbillon voisin. Elles avoient leur mouvement vers ses extremitez, mais ce Tourbillon êtant peut-être differemment pressé par ceux qui l'environnent, est plus rond par en haut, & plus plat par en-bas, & c'est par en-bas qu'il nous regarde. Ces Planetes <UP></UP> qui auront commencé vers le haut à se mouvoir en Cercle, ne prévoyoient pas qu'en bas le Tourbillon leur manqueroit, parce qu'il est là comme écrasé, & pour continuer leur mouvement circulaire, il faut nécessairement qu'elles entrent dans un autre Tourbillon, que je suppose qui est le nôtre, & qu'elles en coupent les extremitez. Aussi sont-elles toûjours fort élevées à notre égard, elles marchent beaucoup au dessus de Saturne. Il est nécessaire dans nôtre Sistême, pour des raisons qui ne sont rien à nôtre suijet present, que depuis Saturne jusqu'aux deux extremitez de nôtre Tourbillon, il y ait un grand espace vide, & sans Planetes. Nos Ennemis nous reprochent sans cesse inutilité de ce grand espace. Qu'ils ne s'inquietent plus, nous en avons trouvé l'usage, c'est l'appartement des Planetes étrangeres qui entrent dans nôtre Monde.</P100>
chunks.target_manual: <P097>Ah! says she, laughing, what kind of Embassadours are those? We might well excuse their Visit, for they serve only to scare people.</P097> <P098>They scare none but Children, said I, because of their extraordinary Equipage, but those Children indeed are many. Comets are only Planets that belong to a neighbouring Vortex. They had their motion toward the extremities, but that Vortex being perhaps differently press'd by those that are round about it, is more round above and flatter below, and 'tis the part below that looks toward us. Those Planets that began their circular motion above, did not foresee that below the Vortex fail'd them; because it is there as it were pressed flat, and to continue their circular motion, they of necessity incroach upon another Vortex, which I suppose to be ours, and cut the extremities of it. They are ever very high, in respect of us, and move far above Saturn. It is necessary in our System, for reasons that are nothing to our present subject that from Saturn to the two extremities of our Vortex, there should be a great void space and without Planets. Our enemies still charge us with the unusefulness of that space; but let them not trouble their Heads, we have found the use of it; tis the Appartment of foreign Planets that come to our World.</P098>
source_segments: elle ne sert qu'à faire peur.
target_segments: they serve only to scare people.
those that are round about it
and cut the extremities of it
let them not trouble their Heads
explanations: The French phrase, where 'elle' (it) refers to 'la visite' (the visit), states that the visit itself serves to scare. The English translation shifts the agent to 'they' (referring to the 'Embassadours'), making it explicit that the ambassadors themselves are the ones scaring. Additionally, the general 'faire peur' (to scare) is made more specific by 'to scare people,' explicitly naming the object of the verb.

The French 'sont en grand nombre' (are in great number/are many), part of the clause 'mais les enfants sont en grand nombre', is translated as 'indeed are many' in 'but those Children indeed are many.' The addition of 'indeed' by the translator makes explicit an emphasis or affirmation of the statement's truth, which was at most implied in the source.

The French 'ceux qui l'environnent' (those that surround it) is translated as 'those that are round about it.' The English phrase 'round about it' is more descriptive and explicitly details the encompassing spatial configuration of the surrounding entities, whereas the French 'environnent' is a more general term for 'surround.'

The French adverbial phrase 'par en-bas' (from below/downwards), found in 'c'est par en-bas qu'il nous regarde', is translated as 'the part below' in ''tis the part below that looks toward us.' The addition of the noun 'part' makes explicit that this refers to a specific section or portion of the Vortex, clarifying information that was only implied by the more general spatial indicator in the source.

The French 'comme écrasé' (as if crushed/squashed), from the phrase 'parce qu'il est là comme écrasé', is translated as 'as it were pressed flat' in 'because it is there as it were pressed flat.' The phrase 'pressed flat' makes explicit the specific manner and resulting shape of the deformation (i.e., becoming flat), clarifying information that was only implied by the more general term 'écrasé' in the source.

The French phrase 'entrent dans un autre Tourbillon' (enter into another Vortex), part of 'qu’elles entrent dans un autre Tourbillon', is translated as 'incroach upon another Vortex' within 'they of necessity incroach upon another Vortex'. The change from the neutral verb 'entrent dans' (enter into) to 'incroach upon' explicitly adds the connotation of intrusion or entering territory improperly. This nuance, if present in the source, was only implicitly suggested by the context, whereas the target text makes it explicit through lexical choice.

The French clitic pronoun 'en' within 'qu'elles en coupent les extremitez' (literally, 'that they of-it cut the extremities'), which refers to 'un autre Tourbillon' (another Vortex), is made explicit as 'of it' in the English phrase 'and cut the extremities of it.' This spells out the referential connection to the previously mentioned Vortex, which was condensed in the French pronoun.

The French 'Qu'ils ne s'inquietent plus' (Let them no longer worry) is translated using the English idiom 'let them not trouble their Heads.' This idiomatic expression expands the general concept of 's'inquiéter' (to worry) by making explicit the notion of mental exertion or agitation ('trouble their Heads'), which was not directly stated in the source.

chunks.source_manual: <P101>J'entends, dit-elle. <NCP></NCP>. Nous ne leur laissons pas d'entrer jusque dans le cur de nôtre Tourbillon, & avec nos Planetes, nous les recevons comme le Grand Seigneur reçoit les Ambassadeurs qu'on luy envoye. Il ne leur fait pas l'honneur de les loger à Constantinople, mais seulement dans un Fauxbourg de la Ville. <IIM>Nous avons encore cela de commun avec les Ottomans</IIM>, repris-je, qu'ils reçoivent des Ambassadeurs sans en renvoyer, & que nous ne renvoyons point de nos Planetes aux Mondes voisins.</P101>
chunks.target_manual: <P099>I understand you well, said she, we suffer them not to enter into the heart of our Vortex, and with our own Planets; but we receive them as the Grand Seignior, receives Embassadours; He doth not honour them with Lodgings in Constantinople, but only in the Suburbs of he Town.</P099>
explanations: The concise French "J'entends" (I understand/I hear) is expanded in the translation to "I understand you well." The addition of "you" makes explicit the implied object of her understanding (the philosopher she is conversing with), which is natural in dialogue. More significantly, the addition of "well" specifies a thoroughness or completeness of understanding that is only implied in the original French phrase, thereby making an implicit degree of comprehension explicit.

The French "nos Planetes" (our planets) is rendered as "our own Planets." While "nos" translates to "our," conveying possession, the addition of "own" by the translator serves to make explicit an implied emphasis on the exclusivity and integral nature of these planets to "nôtre Tourbillon" (our Vortex). In the context of guarding this inner sanctum, the exclusivity of these planets is implied, and "own" spells this out, reinforcing that these are specifically and exclusively their planets, not to be mixed with external entities.

chunks.source_manual: <P102>A en juger par toutes ces choses là, répliqua-t-elle, <UP></UP>. nous sommes bien fiers. Cependant je ne sais pas trop encore ce que j'en dois croire. Ces Planetes étrangeres ont un air bien menaçant avec leurs queües & leurs barbes, & peut- être on nous les envoye pour nous insulter, au lieu que les nôtres, qui ne sont pas faites de la même manière, ne seroient pas si propres à se faire craindre, quand elles iroient dans les autres Mondes.</P102>
chunks.target_manual: <P101>To speak my Opinion, said she, upon the whole matter, we are very rude: in the mean time I know not well that I ought to believe. These foreign Planets have a very menacing Air with their Tails and Beards, and perhaps they are sent to insult us; whereas ours, that are not made after the same manner, are not so proper to cause Fear, should they be sent into other Worlds.</P101>
explanations: The French "toutes ces choses là" (all those things), which refers to the sum of previously discussed points, is rendered in the context of the larger phrase "To speak my Opinion, said she, upon the whole matter". The specific English phrase "upon the whole matter" explicitly clarifies and emphasizes that the Marquise's opinion is based on the entirety of the subject discussed, making the comprehensiveness implied by "toutes" (all) more direct and emphatic.

The French "fiers" (proud, implying arrogance or haughtiness in this context) describes a state of being or an attitude. The English translation "rude" makes explicit a potential social or behavioral consequence of this pride. It spells out that such human-centric "fierté" could manifest as impoliteness or disrespect ("rudeness") in the broader cosmic context, an aspect that is an interpretation or implied consequence rather than the direct meaning of "fiers."

The French "Cependant" primarily functions here as an adversative conjunction (e.g., "however," "yet"), creating a contrast with the preceding statement. The English translation "in the mean time" shifts the emphasis to a temporal aspect, explicitly framing the Marquise's uncertainty as existing "for now" or during the course of the ongoing conversation. This foregrounds a temporal nuance that was, at best, secondary or merely potential in the original's primary adversative use of "Cependant."

The French verb "iroient" (from *aller* - to go; meaning "would go" or "were to go") is in the active voice and describes a hypothetical movement without specifying its cause or agent. The English translation uses "be sent" (within the phrase "should they be sent"), which is a passive construction. This change makes explicit the idea of an external agent or force being responsible for initiating or causing this movement, an agency that was not stated in the original French verb.

chunks.source_manual: <P103>Les queües & les barbes, répondis-je, ne sont que de pures apparences. <UP></UP>. Les Planetes étrangères ne diffèrent en rien des nôtres, mais en entrant dans nütre Tourbillon, elles prennent la queüe ou la barbe par une certaine sorte d'illumination qu'elles reçoivent du Soleil, & qui entre nous n'a pas encore êté trop bien expliquée; mais toûjours on est sûr qu'il ne s'agit que d'une espèce d'illumination <UP></UP>; on la devinera quand on pourra. Je voudrois donc bien, reprit- elle, que nôtre Saturne allât prendre une queuë ou une barbe dans quelque autre Tourbillon, & y répandre l'effroy, & qu'en suite ayant mis bas cet <IIM>accompagnement</IIM> terrible, il revint se ranger ici avec les autres Planetes à ses fonctions ordinaires. Il vaut mieux pour luy, répondis-je, qu'il ne sorte point de nôtre Tourbillon. Je vous ay dit le choc qui se fait à l'endroit où deux Tourbillons se poussent & se repoussent l'un l'autre; je croy que dans ce pas là une pauvre Planete est agitée assez rudement, & que ses Habitans ne s'en portent pas mieux. Nous croyons nous autres être bien malheureux quand il nous paroît une Comete elle-même qui est bien malheureuse. Je ne le crois point, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle nous apporte tous ses Habitans en bonne santé. Rien n'est si divertissant que de changer ainsi de Tourbillon. Nous qui ne sortons jamais du nôtre, nous menons une vie assez ennuyeuse. Si les Habitans d'une Comete ont assez d'esprit pour prévoir le temps de leur passage dans notre Monde, ceux qui ont déjà fait le voyage, annoncent aux autres par avance ce qu'ils y verront. Vous découvrirez bien-tôt une Planete qui a un grand Anneau autour d'elle, disent-ils peut-être en parlant de Saturne. Vous en verrez une autre qui en a quatre petites qui la suivent. Peut-être même y a-t-il des Gens destinés à observer le moment où ils entrent dans notre Monde, & qui crient aussi-tôt._Nouveau Soleil, Nouveau Soleil, comme ces Matelots qui crient, Terre, Terre. <UP></UP>.</P103>
chunks.target_manual: <P102>Those Tails and Beards, said I, are meer Appearances, those foreign Planets differ nothing from ours, but at their entrance into our Vortex, they take the Tail and Beard by a certain strong Illumination of the Sun, which has not yet been well explained between us; but yet we are sure it acts only by a kind of Illumination; we'l judge more certainly of it when we can.</P102> <P103>I should be very willing then, said she, that Saturn would take a Tail or a Beard in some other Vortex, and spread a Fear there, and having laid aside his terrible Equipage, return and range himself with the other Planets in his ordinary Function.</P103> <P104>'Tis better, said I, for him, that he should not stir at all out of our Vortex; I have told you what a shock two Vortices make when they push against one another, I believe the poor Planet is then handled rudely enough, and the Inhabitants are not much more at ease. We believe we are unhappy when a Comet appears, whereas 'tis the Comet it self that is unhappy.</P104> <P105>I do not believe so, said the Marchioness, it brings us all its Inhabitants in good health. Nothing is so diverting as that change of Vortex; We who never stir out of ours, lead a life uneasie enough. If the Inhabitants of a Comet have wit enough to foresee the time of their passage into our World, those who have already made the Voyage, discover to the others beforehand, what they shall see there. You will presently see a Planet with a great Ring about it, say they, perhaps speaking of Saturn, you will see another that has four little ones following it: perhaps likewise there are people appointed to observe the very moment of their entrance into our World, who cry A new Sun, a new Sun, as the Seamen cry Land, land.</P105>

explanations: The French "ne s'en portent pas mieux" is a somewhat general idiomatic expression indicating that the inhabitants fare worse or are negatively affected. The English translation "are not much more at ease" makes this implied negative consequence more explicit by specifying the nature of their condition as a lack of ease or comfort, thus clarifying the more general statement about their well-being from the source text.

The French "le moment où ils entrent" (the moment when they enter) specifies a particular point in time. The English translation "the very moment of their entrance" adds "very" and uses a nominal construction. The addition of "very" explicitly emphasizes the exactness and singularity of this instant. While precision is implied by "le moment où" in the context of people "destinés à observer" (appointed to observe), "very" makes this implied exactitude more salient and rhetorically emphatic, spelling out a nuance that was previously only suggested by the context.

chunks.source_manual: <P104>Il ne faut donc plus songer, luy dis-je, à vous donner de la pitié pour les Habitans d'une Comète, mais j'espère du moins que vous plaindrez ceux qui vivent dans un Tourbillon dont le Soleil vient à s'éteindre, & <SC>qui demeurent dans une nuit éternelle</SC>. Quoi? s'écria-t-elle, des Soleils s'éteignent? Oüi, sans doute, répondis-je. Les Anciens ont vû dans le Ciel des Etoiles Fixes que nous n'y voyons plus. Ces Soleils ont perdu leur lumière; grande desolation assurément dans tout le Tourbillon; mortalité generale sur toutes les Planetes; car que faire sans Soleil? Cette idée est trop funeste, reprit-elle. N'y auroit-il pas moyen de me l'épargner? Je vous diray, si vous voulez, répondis je, ce que disent de fort habiles Gens, que les Etoiles Fixes qui ont disparu ne sont pas pour cela éteintes, que ce sont des Soleils qui ne le sont qu'à demy, c'est-à-dire qui ont <IIM>une moitié obscure</IIM>, & l'autre lumineuse; que comme ils tournent sur eux-mêmes, tantôt ils nous présentent la moitié lumineuse, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons, tantôt la moitié obscure, & qu'alors nous ne les voyons plus. Je prendray bien pour vous obliger cette opinion-là, qui est plus douce que l'autre, mais je ne puis la prendre qu'à l'égard de certaines Etoiles qui ont des temps reglez pour paroître & pour disparoître, ainsi qu'on a commencé à s'en apercevoir, autrement les demy Soleils ne peuvent pas subsister. Mais que dirons nous des Etoiles qui disparoissent & ne se remontrent pas aprés le temps pendant lequel elles auroient dû assurément achever de tourner sur elles-mêmes? Vous êtes trop équitable pour vouloir m'obliger à croire que ce soient des demy Soleils: cependant je feray encore un effort en votre faveur. Ces Soleils ne se seront pas éteints, ils se seront seulement enfoncez dans la profondeur immense du Ciel, & nous ne pourrons plus les voir. En ce cas le Tourbillon aura suivy son Soleil, & tout s'y portera bien. Il est vray que la plus grande partie des Etoiles Fixes n'ont pas ce mouvement par lequel elles s'éloignent de nous, car en d'autres temps elles devroient s'en rapprocher, & nous les verrions tantôt plus grandes tantôt plus petites, ce qui n'arrive pas. Mais nous supposerons qu'il n'y a que quelques petits Tourbillons plus légers & plus agiles qui se glissent entre les autres, & font de certains tours, au bout desquels ils reviennent, tandis que le gros des Tourbillons demeure immobile; mais voicy un étrange malheur. Il y a des Etoiles Fixes qui viennent se montrer à nous, qui passent beaucoup de temps à ne faire que paroître & disparoître, & enfin disparoissent entièrement, des demi-Soleils reparoîtraient dans des temps reglez. Des Soleils qui s'enfonceroient dans le Ciel ne disparoîtroient qu'une fois pour ne reparoître de longtemps. Prenez votre resolution, Madame, avec courage; il faut que ces Etoiles soient des Soleils qui s'obscurcissent assez pour cesser d'être visibles à nos yeux, & en suite se rallument, & à la fin s'éteignent tout à fait. Comment un Soleil peut-il s'obscurcir & s'éteindre, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, luy qui est en lui-même une source de lumière? Le plus aisément du Monde, selon Descartes, notre Soleil a des tâches. Que ce soient ou des écumes, des brouillards ou tout ce qu'il vous plaira, ces tâches peuvent s'épaissir, se mettre plusieurs ensemble, s'accrocher les unes aux autres, en suite elles iront jusqu'à former autour du Soleil une croûte qui s'augmentera toûjours, & adieu le Soleil <UP></UP>. Nous l'avons déja même échepée, dit-on. Le Soleil a été très pâle pendant des années entières, pendant celle, par exemple, qui suivit la mort de Cesar. C'étoit la croûte qui commençoit à se faire; la force du Soleil la rompit & la dissipa, mais si elle eût continué, nous étions perdus. Vous me faites trembler, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Presentement que je say les consequences de la pâleur du Soleil, je crois qu'au lieu d'aller voir les matins à mon miroir si je ne suis point pâle, j'iray voir au Ciel si le Soleil ne l'est point luy même. Ah! Madame, répondis-je, rassurez-vous, il faut du temps pour ruiner un Monde. Mais enfin, dit-elle, il ne faut que du temps? Je vous l'avouë, repris- je. Toute cette masse immense de matiere qui compose l'Univers, est dans un mouvement perpétuel, dont aucune de ses parties n'est entierement exempte; & dés qu'il y a du mouvement quelque part, ne vous y fiez point, il faut qu'il arrive des changements, soit lents, soit prompts, mais toûjours dans des temps proportionnez à l'effet. Les Anciens êtaient <IIM>plaisants</IIM> de s'imaginer que les Corps celestes étoient de nature à ne changer jamais, parce qu'ils ne les avoient pas encore vû changer. <IIM>Avoient-ils eu le loisir de s'en assurer par l'expérience?</IIM> Les Anciens étoient jeunes auprés de nous. Si les Roses qui ne durent qu'un jour faisoient des Histoires, & se loissent des Memoires les unes aux autres, les premieres auroient fait le portrait de leur Jardinier d'une certaine façon, & de plus de quinze mille áges de Rose, les autres qui l'auroient encore laissé à celles qui les devoient suivre, n'y auroient rien changé. Sur cela, elles diroient nous avons toûjours vû le même Jardinier <UP></UP>, de memoire de Rose on n'a vû que luy, il a toûjours êté fait comme il est, assurément il ne meurt point comme nous, il ne change seulement pas. Le raisonnement des Roses seroit-il bon? Il auroit pourtant plus de fondement que celuy que faisoient les Anciens sur les Corps celestes; & quand même il ne seroit arrivé aucun changement dans les Cieux jusqu'à aujourd'huy, quand ils paroîtroient marquer qu'ils seroient faits pour durer toûjours sans aucune alteration, je ne les en croirois pas encore, j'attendrois une plus longue experience. Devons-nous établir notre durée, qui n'est que d'un instant, pour la mesure de quelque autre? Seroit-ce à dire que ce qui auroit duré cent mille fois plus que nous, dût toûjours durer? On n'est pas si aisément éternel. Il faudroit qu'une chose eût passé bien des âges d'homme mis à bout pour commencer à donner quelque signe d'immortalité. Vrayment, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je voy les Mondes bien éloignez d'y pouvoir pretendre. Je ne leur ferois seulement pas l'honneur de les comparer à ce Jardinier qui dure tant à l'égard des Roses; ils ne sont que comme les Roses même qui naissent & qui meurent dans un Jardin les unes aprés les autres; car je m'attends bien que s'il disparoît des Etoiles anciennes, il en paroît de nouvelles, il faut que l'espce se repare. Il n'est pas à craindre qu'elle perisse, répondis-je. Les uns vous diront que ce ne sont que des Soleils qui se rapprochent de nous aprés avoir eté long- temps perdus pour nous dans la profondeur du Ciel. D'autres vous diront que ce sont des Soleils qui se sont démefez de cette croûte obscure qui commençoit à les environner. Je crois aisément que tout cela peut être, mais je croy aussi que l'Univers peut avoir êté fait de sorte qu'il s'y formera de temps en temps des Soleils nouveaux. Pourquoy la matiere propre à faire un Soleil ne pourra-t'elle pas, aprés avoir êté dispersée en plusieurs endroits différents, se ramasser à la longue en un certain lieu, & y jetter les fondements d'un nouveau Monde? J'ay d'autant plus d'inclination à croire ces nouvelles productions, qu'elles répondent mieux à la haute idée que j'ay des ouvrages de la Nature. N'auroit-elle le secret que de faire naître & mourir des herbes ou des plantes par une revolution continuelle? Je suis persuadé, & vous l'êtes déja aussi, qu'elle pratique ce même secret sur les Mondes, & qu'il ne luy en coûte pas davantage. De bonne foy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je trouve à present les Mondes, les Cieux, & les Corps celestes si sujets au changement, que m'en voila tout à fait revenuë. Revenons encore mieux, si vous m'en croyez, répliquai-je, n'en parlons plus, aussi bien vous voila arrivée à la derniere voûte des Cieux; & pour vous dire s'il y a encore des Etoiles au-delà, il faudroit être plus habile que je ne suis. Mettez-y encore des Mondes, n'y en mettez pas, cela dépend de vous. C'est proprement l'Empire des Philosophes que ces grands païs invisibles qui peuvent être ou n'être pas si on veut, ou être tels que l'on veut, il me suffit d'avoir mené vôtre esprit aussi loin que vont vos yeux.</P104>
chunks.target_manual: <P106>I need not then, continued I, think any more of persuading you to pity the Inhabitants of a Comet, but I hope, at least, you will compassionate those that live in a Vortex where the Sun is extinct <SC>—</SC>. How! cry'd she, Suns extinct? Yes, doubtless, said I, the Ancients saw fixed Stars in the Heavens which we do not see now, those Suns have lost their Light. A great desolation most certainly in the whole Vortex, a general mortality among all the Planets for what's to be done without a Sun? That Idea, said he, is too sad, can you no way excuse me that? I'le tell you, if you please, says I, what knowing men say; That those fixed Stars which have disappear'd, are not therefore extinct, but that they are Demy Suns, that is to say, which have the one half obscure and the other luminous; and as they turn upon their own Axis they sometimes present us the luminous side, and then we see them, sometimes the obscure side, and then we see them not. I would, to oblige you, hold this Opinion, which is more moderate than the other; but I can hold it only in respect of certain Stars which have regulated times of appearing and disappearing, as is begun to be discover'd in some, otherwise the Demy Suns could not subsist. But what shall we say of those Stars that have disappear'd, and were never seen since; though in all this time they might most certainly have perform'd their Course upon their Axis. You are too just to oblige me to believe that they are Demy Suns, but yet I'le make another Essay in your favour. Those Suns shall not be extinct, they shall be only sunk into the immense profundity of Heaven, beyond the reach of our eye. In such case, the Vortex follow'd its Sun, and all's well. 'Tis true that the greatest part of the fixed Stars have not that motion, by which they remove themselves from us; for then at other times they ought to return to us, and we should see them sometimes bigger, sometimes less, which doth not happen. But we'l suppose that there are only some little Vortices lighter, and more agil, that slip in among the other, and having taken certain turns at the end of their Course they return, while the great Vortices remain immovable. But here's the mischief, there are fixed Stars, which come and shew themselves to us, and continue long in only appearing and disappearing, and at last wholly disappear. Demy Suns would appear again at regular times. Suns that sunk into the depth of Heaven would disappear but once for a long time. Now resolve, Madam, couragiously, those Stars must be Suns that obscure themselves enough not to be visible to our eyes, and they afterward take light again, and at last are wholly extinct. How can a Sun, says the Marchioness, obscure and extinguish it self, a Sun that is in it self a Source and Spring of Light? The most easily in the world, says I, according to Des Cartes. Our Sun has Spots, which are Froth, or Scum, or Mists, or what ever you please, those Spots may condense, many of them gather together and close one with another; at last they may go so far as to form a kind of a Crust about the Sun, and then farewel Sun. We have already fairly escap'd it, they say. The Sun has been very pale for some whole years together, as for example, the year after the death of Cesar; it was the Crust that began then to grow upon the Sun, but by the force of the Sun it was dissipated, had it continued we had been undone.</P106> <P107>You make me tremble, said the Marchioness, I know now the Consequences of the paleness of the Sun, I believe in stead of going to see in my Glass in a morning if I am pale, I shall look toward Heaven, to see if the Sun be so.</P107> <P108>Ah! Madam, said I, take courage, 'twill require time to ruine a World. But still, says she, time will do it. I confess it, said I, all this immense heap of matter, which makes up the Universe, is in perpetual motion, and no part of it wholly exempt; since then there is a motion in every part, trust it not, there must be a change, be it slow or be it swift, but still in time proportionable to the effect. The Ancients had a pleasant fancy that the celestial bodies were unchangeable, because they never saw a change in them; but had they time enough to confirm their Opinion by experience? the Ancients were young in respect of us. Should the Roses, which live but a day, write their own Story, and leave their Memoirs from one to another, the first would make a Description of their Gardiner after one certain fashion, and for more than fifteen thousand Ages of Roses, those that should leave their Story to Posterity would make no alteration; from whence they would reason thus, We have ever seen the same Gardin•r; our History tells us of no other, he was ever made as he is; certainly he dyes not as we do, nor ever changes. Would this be good Reasoning of the Roses? and yet they would have better ground for it, than the Ancients had for their Opinion of the Celestial bodies. And were it so that the Heavens had suffer'd no change to this day, had they in themselves any Sign or Character of an eternal duration without change, yet I should not believe it, but wait for farther satisfaction from a longer experience. Ought we to establish our Duration, which is but of a moment, by the measures of another? Can we argue that what has continued a hundred thousand times longer than we, will endure for ever? Eternity is not so easily acquir'd. A thing must have out-liv'd many Ages of Man, to begin only to give a sign of its Immortality.</P108> <P109>Truly, said the Marchioness, I find the World's very far from any reason of pretending to it; I would not do them the honour so much as to compare them to the Gardiner that survives so many Roses, they are but even as the Roses themselves that spring up and perish in the same Garden one after another; for I observe that if some ancient Stars have disappear'd, new ones have succeeded, and still there must be a reparation of the Species.</P109> <P110>There is no fear of their perishing, said I; some will tell you they are only Suns that return after a long time being lost to us in the profundity of Heaven, others will say, they are Suns that have disingag'd themselves from that obscure Crust that began to inclose them. This I easily believe may be, but I believe likewise that the Universe is so made that new Suns may be form'd in it from time to time, why may not the matter proper to make a Sun, after having been long dispers'd in several places, at last congregate it self in one certain place, and lay the foundations of a new World? I am the rather inclin'd to believe these new productions, because they agree better with those great Ideas I have of the works of Nature. Has not she the secret of causing Herbs and Plants to spring and dye in a continual Revolution? I am persuaded, and you are so likewise, that the practises the same secret in the Worlds, and it costs her no more to do it.</P110> <P111>In good Faith, says the Marchioness, I find the Worlds, the Heavens and Celestial bodies so subject to change, that I have e'en left them.</P111> <P112>Let us leave them more yet, said I, if you'l be persuaded by me, and talk no more of them; for you are now come to the highest Roof of Heaven, and to tell you whether there be Stars beyond that or not, will require more knowledge than I have. Place Worlds there, or place them not, 'twill depend upon your self. The Empire of Philosophers is properly in those great invisible Country's, which may be or not be, according as they please, and be such as they please to make them. To me it suffises that I have led your thoughts as far as you can reach with your eyes.</P112>

explanations: The French "la profondeur immense du Ciel" (the immense depth of Heaven) implies that stars sunk there would become invisible. The translation makes this implication explicit by adding the clause "beyond the reach of our eye," which clarifies that "immense profundity" signifies a distance so great it renders objects invisible, spelling out the visual consequence of such depth.

The French "une source de lumière" (a source of light) is translated as "a Source and Spring of Light." The addition of "and Spring" expands the original phrase, making the idea of a continuous, generative origin of light more explicit and vivid, thereby emphasizing the nature of a sun.

The French "des écumes, des brouillards" (scums/froths, mists) is translated as "Froth, or Scum, or Mists." The word "écume" can mean either froth or scum. By translating it as "Froth, or Scum," the translator explicitly provides both potential meanings, thereby expanding the description of the sunspots' composition.

The French pronominal verb "s'en assurer" (to make sure of it / ascertain it) contains the pronoun "en" (of it), which implicitly refers to the Ancients' previously stated belief that celestial bodies were unchangeable. The translation "to confirm their Opinion" makes this implicit antecedent explicit by naming it "their Opinion," clarifying what the Ancients needed to verify through experience.

The French "de memoire de Rose on n'a vû que luy" (literally, 'by rose's memory one has only seen him') is an idiomatic expression. The translation "our History tells us of no other" explicitly interprets "memoire de Rose" as a collective, recorded account akin to "History," and changes the impersonal "on n'a vû" (one has seen) to a more active "our History tells us," clarifying how this 'memory' is conveyed.

The French "quand ils paroîtroient marquer" (even if they seemed to indicate/show) describes a general appearance of showing something. The translation "had they in themselves any Sign or Character" explicates *how* this indication of permanence might occur, by specifying that it would be through intrinsic "Signs or Characters," thus adding clarifying detail about the nature of the supposed evidence.

The French "j'attendrois une plus longue experience" (I would wait for a longer experience) states an intention. The translation "but wait for farther satisfaction from a longer experience" adds the phrase "farther satisfaction from," which explicitly states the *purpose* or desired outcome of waiting for longer experience (i.e., to gain more satisfactory evidence), a motivation only implied in the source.

The French "il faut que l'espce se repare" (the species must repair/replenish itself) is translated as "and still there must be a reparation of the Species." The use of the capitalized "Species" and the formal noun phrase "reparation of" makes the concept more specific, explicitly referring to the cosmic category of stars/worlds and the need for its systematic renewal, which is a more abstract and formal interpretation than the general French verb.

The French idiomatic phrase "que m'en voila tout à fait revenuë" (literally 'that I have completely come back from it') signifies being completely disabused of a notion. The pronoun "en" (from it) implicitly refers to her previous beliefs about celestial bodies. The translation "that I have e'en left them" makes the object of her changed perspective explicit as "them" (the worlds, heavens, celestial bodies) and uses the concrete verb "left" to describe her abandonment of these prior notions.

The French "Revenons encore mieux" (literally 'Let's come back from it even better/more thoroughly') idiomatically suggests further disengaging from a previous idea. Consistent with the translator's rendering of "revenuë" as "left them," this is translated as "Let us leave them more yet." This choice explicitly states the action of further abandoning the topic or prior notions ("leave them more yet"), making the speaker's desire to move on more concrete.

The French "aussi loin que vont vos yeux" (as far as your eyes go) is translated as "as far as you can reach with your eyes." The addition of "you can reach with" explicitly clarifies that "vont vos yeux" refers to the limit of visual perception or capability, rather than merely the direction in which the eyes are looking, thereby specifying the nature of this boundary.

chunks.source_manual: <P105>Quoi, s'écria-t-elle, j'ay dans la tête tout le systeme de l'Univers! Je suis savante! Oüy, répliquay-je, vous l'êtes assez raisonnablement, & vous l'êtes avec la commodité de pouvoir ne rien croire de tout ce que je vous ay dit dés que l'envie vous en prendra. Je vous demande seulement pour recompense de mes peines de ne voir jamais le Soleil, ny le Ciel, ny les Etoiles, sans songer à moy.</P105>
chunks.target_manual: <P113>So, says she, I have now the whole System of the Universe in my Head; I am now a knowing Woman.</P113> <P114>You are, said I, reasonable enough, and you are so with this conveniency, that you may believe nothing of all that I have said to you, till you please your self. I only request, as a Recompence for my pains, that you will never look upon the Sun, Heaven or Stars without thinking on me.</P114>
explanations: The French "Quoi" is an interjection primarily expressing surprise or marking a sharp reaction. While it implies a response to the preceding discourse, the English "So" functions more directly as a conclusive or resumptive discourse marker. This translation makes the logical connection explicit – that the Marquise's following statements are a consequence or summary of what she has just learned – a connection that was only implied by the conversational flow in the original.

The French present tense "j'ay" (I have) implies a current state of possession of knowledge. The English translation "I have now" makes the temporal immediacy of this possession explicit by adding "now," clarifying that this understanding of the universe is a newly acquired state resulting from the preceding conversation.

The French present tense "Je suis" (I am) implies a current state of being. The English translation "I am now" makes the temporal immediacy and newness of this state (of being "savante" or knowledgeable) explicit by adding "now," emphasizing that this is a current reality just realized by the Marquise as a result of the dialogue.
